ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1.1. - Title. 
    These regulations shall be entitled the "Consolidated Land Development Regulations" or "Code" of the City of South Daytona and may be referred to herein as the "Code." 
A.  Authority. This Consolidated Land Development Code is enacted pursuant to the requirements and authority of Chapter 163, Part II, Florida Statutes (the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act), the City Charter, Chapter 166, Florida Statutes, and the residual home rule powers granted to municipalities under the Florida Constitution. 
Sec. 1.2. - Findings. 
A.  General findings. 
1.  Chapter 163, Part II, Florida Statutes, requires the city to enact a Consolidated Land Development Code which implements and is consistent with the local Comprehensive Plan, and which contains all land development regulations for the City of South Daytona. 
2.  Regulating the location, design and construction of development within the city is necessary to maintain and improve the quality of life in the city. 
B.  Relationship to comprehensive plan. It is the intention of the city council and local planning agency that this ordinance serve to implement the requirements of the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act, Chapter 163.3202 of the Florida Statutes, that requires the adoption of Land Development Regulations, and compliance with the requirements of the Florida Department of Community Affairs (DCA) Rule 9J-29, Florida Administrative Code (F.A.C.). These Land Development Regulations specifically address the following provisions: 
1.  The implementation of the regulations specifically stated in the adopted policies of the South Daytona Comprehensive Plan; 
2.  The regulation of signage; 
3.  The protection, preservation, or introduction of trees or other natural or planted flora and fauna; 
4.  The provision of safe and convenient on-site traffic flow, considering the need for vehicle parking and pedestrian movement; 
5.  The protection of potable water supply sources through the control of land uses and activities within the identified cones of influence and general areas of influence for the City of South Daytona's wells and wellfields; 
6.  The regulation of the areas subject to seasonal and periodic flooding and the provision of drainage and stormwater management through the control or use of construction techniques within these areas; 
7.  The protection of environmentally sensitive lands designated in the comprehensive plan, particularly the wetlands areas identified in the conservation element; 
8.  The regulation of the use of land and water for the use categories included in the South Daytona Comprehensive Plan as implemented by a set of zoning districts and a zoning map; 
9.  The provision of public facilities and services concurrent with the impacts of development based upon adopted levels of service (LOS); 
10.  The subdivision of land, including provisions that meet the statutory requirements of Chapter 177, Part I, F.S., including review procedures, design and development standards, provisions for adequate public facilities, mitigation of development impacts, land dedications, fees and administrative provisions; 
11.  In the event of a conflict between these regulations and the comprehensive plan, the comprehensive plan shall prevail. 
Sec. 1.3. - Specific findings relating to the various subject areas of this Code. 
    With regard to the following specific subject areas of this Code, the city council finds: 
A.  Administration and enforcement. 
1.  A single set of administrative procedures for making all land use decisions promotes efficiency, predictability, and citizen participation. 
2.  All development proposals should undergo a development review process to assure compliance with the requirements of this Code. 
B.  Signs. 
1.  The manner of erection, the location and the maintenance of signs affects the public health, safety, morals and welfare of the residents of the city. 
2.  The safety of motorists, cyclists, pedestrians and other users of the public streets is affected by the number, size, location, and appearance of signs that divert the attention of drivers. 
3.  The construction, erection and maintenance of large signs suspended from or placed on the tops of buildings, walls or other structures constitutes a direct danger to pedestrian and vehicular traffic, especially during periods of strong winds. 
4.  Uncontrolled placement and unlimited numbers of signs degrade the aesthetic attractiveness of the natural and manmade attributes of the city thereby undermining the economic value of tourism, visitation and permanent economic growth. 
5.  Due to the city's predominate residential character, billboards, banners, and off-premises signs as defined in this Code are determined to have an adverse impact on the aesthetics of the city. It is determined that on-premises signs are generally sufficient to provide advertising for nonresidential uses within the city. 
C.  Landscaping and tree protection. 
1.  Landscaping and buffering of development with trees and other vegetation promotes the health, safety and welfare of the city sufficient to justify the imposition of landscaping and buffering requirements. 
2.  Trees and landscaping benefit the city by performing, among other functions, the following; 
a.  Absorbing carbon dioxide and returning oxygen to the atmosphere; 
b.  Precipitating dust and other particulates from the air; 
c.  Providing wildlife habitat, particularly for birds, which in turn help control insects; 
d.  Providing soil stabilization, which reduces erosion and mitigates the effect of flooding; 
e.  Providing shade which reduces energy consumption and glare, making outdoor areas more comfortable during the warm months; 
f.  Making developed property more attractive by adding a variety of color, shape and pattern of foliage, thus increasing community pride and the stability of neighborhoods; 
g.  Providing attractive buffering between incompatible land uses; and 
h.  Abating noise. 
3.  Native vegetation shall be promoted since it has adapted to local diseases, pests, soil and climate, and is generally more economical and desirable than exotic species which require more pesticide, fertilizer and water. 
4.  Because some trees are more beneficial than others, the public benefits of tree protection may be obtained without preserving each and every tree. 
5.  Mangrove trees are especially valuable in stabilizing, building and protecting the shoreline, providing for spawning and breeding grounds for marine organisms and other wildlife, and serving as the basis for most of the estuarine food chains, which are critical to a substantial majority of those species considered important from a recreational and/or commercial standpoint. 
D.  Traffic management. 
1.  Off-street parking and loading of vehicles promote the public safety and welfare by reducing traffic congestion. 
2.  Well-designed off-street parking and loading areas promote the safe and efficient storage, loading and circulation of vehicles. 
3.  Allowing the use of porous paving materials and unpaved parking areas, whenever practical to do so, aids the recharge of surficial aquifers, moderates the microclimate, and reduces the expense and hazards of controlling stormwater runoff. 
E.  Stormwater management. 
1.  Surface water runoff carries pollutants into receiving water bodies, degrading quality; 
2.  The increase in nutrients such as phosphorus and nitrogen accelerates eutrophication of receiving waters, adversely affecting flora and fauna; 
3.  Improperly channeling water increases the velocity of runoff, thereby increasing erosion; 
4.  Construction requiring the alteration of natural topography and removal of vegetation increases erosion; 
5.  Siltation of water bodies resulting from increased erosion decreases their capacity to hold and transport water, interferes with navigation, and harms flora and fauna; 
6.  Changes in the elevation of land may create or aggravate drainage problems on adjacent land; 
7.  Impervious surfaces increase the volume and rate of surface water runoff, allowing less water to percolate into the soil and thereby decreasing groundwater recharge; 
8.  Improperly managed surface water runoff increases the incidence of flooding and the level of floods which occur, thereby destroying property and causing loss of life; 
9.  Improperly managed surface water runoff interferes with the maintenance of optimum salinity in estuarine areas; 
10.  Economic losses result from these adverse impacts on community waters; and 
11.  Future problems can be avoided if developers provide for drainage in accordance with this chapter. 
F.  Floodplain protection. 
1.  Flooding is a natural, recurring phenomenon in the city. 
2.  Naturally flood-prone lands serve the following important functions in the regional hydrologic cycle and ecological system: 
a.  They provide natural storage and conveyance of flood waters. 
b.  They facilitate groundwater recharge. 
c.  They provide temporary storage of surface waters that moderates flood elevations and the timing, velocity and rate of flood discharges. 
d.  They reduce erosion, and filter nutrients, sediments, and other pollutants from flood waters. 
e.  They export detritus and other food sources to open water bodies and are vital habitat for fish, birds, wildlife and native plant communities. 
3.  Naturally occurring flooding may provide recharge to groundwater and a basic source of flow to surface waters. 
4.  The uncontrolled development of flood-prone lands substantially degrades the health, safety and welfare of the community in the following ways: 
a.  The owners, residents, customers, guests, and employees occupying homes, businesses and other structures located in flood-prone areas are placed at unreasonable risk of personal injury and property damage. 
b.  Expensive and dangerous search, rescue and disaster relief operations may be necessary when developed properties are flooded. 
c.  Roads, public facilities, and utilities associated with development may be damaged by flooding at great expense to taxpayers and rate payers. 
d.  Flooding of developed properties may lead to demands that the city construct expensive and environmentally damaging projects to control flood waters. 
e.  Normally flood-free lands are placed at risk of flooding when flood waters on natural flood-prone areas are obstructed, diverted, displaced or channelized by development. 
f.  Water quality is degraded, the supply of fresh water to estuaries is disrupted, and habitat is lost. 
g.  Property values are lowered and economic activity is disrupted by damaging floods. 
G.  Protection of environmentally sensitive lands/resources. 
1.  Protection of environmentally sensitive lands described or mapped in the coastal management/conservation element of the comprehensive plan promotes the well being of the residents of the city. 
2.  Shorelines serve the following beneficial functions: 
a.  Land adjoining waters, which can generally be divided into submerged, transitional, and upland vegetation zones, provides essential habitat for many plant and animal species, including species that are endangered, threatened, or of special concern. 
b.  Submerged, transitional, and upland vegetation zones serve as effective buffers against noise and other human activities which may have adverse effects on aquatic-dependent wildlife. 
c.  Submerged, transitional, and upland vegetation zones help slow stormwater runoff flows and increase infiltration of water, nutrients, and other substances into the soil. 
d.  Submerged, transitional, and upland vegetation zones reduce predation by domestic pets on wetland and wetland dependent wildlife species. 
H.  Land and water use regulations. 
1.  The regulation of the nature, rate, location and timing of development shall be conducted in an orderly fashion, commensurate with state, county and local laws, the comprehensive plan, and other applicable regulatory measures. 
2.  Zoning and subdivision regulations are necessary means to assure proper development, division and use of parcels in the city. 
I.  Concurrency management. Services and facilities should function at an established standard as defined in the South Daytona Comprehensive Plan so as to promote the general safety and welfare of the community. 
J.  Subdivision. The regulation of the division of land through provisions that meet the statutory requirements of Chapter 177, Part I, F.S. are necessary to: create review procedures, provide design and development standards, provide for adequate public facilities, mitigate development impacts, govern land dedications, and set fees. 
Sec. 1.4. - Intent. 
    The provisions of this Land Development Code shall be construed and implemented to achieve the following intentions and purposes: 
A.  To establish the regulations, procedures and standards for review and approval of all proposed development in the city. 
B.  To foster and preserve public health, safety, comfort and welfare, and to aid in the harmonious and orderly development of the city in accordance with the comprehensive plan. 
C.  To adopt a development review process that is: 
1.  Efficient, in terms of time and expenses; 
2.  Effective, in terms of addressing the natural resource and public facility implications of proposed development; and 
3.  Equitable, in terms of consistency with established regulations and procedures, respect for the rights of property owners, and consideration of the interests of the city and its citizens. 
D.  To implement the city comprehensive plan. 
Sec. 1.5. - Specific intent relating to the various subject areas of this Code. 
    The provisions of this Code shall be implemented and construed to achieve the following intentions and purposes regarding the areas regulated by this Code: 
A.  Administration and enforcement. 
1.  To assure that all development proposals are thoroughly and efficiently reviewed for compliance with the requirements of this Code. 
2.  To promote efficiency, predictability and citizen participation. 
3.  To assure compliance with approved development orders and the provisions of this Code through rigorous but fair enforcement actions. 
B.  Signs. 
1.  To create a comprehensive and balanced system of sign control which accommodates both the need for a well maintained, safe and attractive city, and the need for effective business identification, advertising and communication. 
2.  To permit signs that are: 
a.  Compatible with their surroundings. 
b.  Designed, constructed, installed and maintained in a manner which does not endanger public safety or unduly distract motorists. 
c.  Appropriate to the type of activity to which they pertain. 
d.  Large enough to convey sufficient information about the owner or occupants of a particular property, the products or services available on the property, or the activities conducted on the property, and small enough to satisfy the needs for regulation. 
e.  Reflective of the identity and special characteristics of individual occupants. 
C.  Landscaping and tree protection. 
1.  To enhance the attractiveness of the city. 
2.  To conserve energy through the cooling and shading effects of trees. 
3.  To mitigate and/or abate the effects of noise, glare, heat, air pollution and stormwater runoff. 
4.  To mitigate conflicts between adjoining land uses; 
5.  To preserve the environmental and ecological benefits of existing native trees and vegetation. 
6.  To preserve the city's irreplaceable natural heritage for existing and future generations. 
7.  To reflect the ecological characteristics of the community or zones therein and thereby assure appropriate growing conditions. 
D.  Traffic management. To assure that all development provides adequate and safe storage and movement of vehicles in a manner consistent with good engineering and site design principles. 
1.  To promote safe and efficient use of off-street parking facilities and other vehicular use areas by: 
a.  Clearly delineating and buffering the bounds of vehicular use areas, particularly where they abut public rights-of-way, so that movement, noise, and glare in one area do not adversely distract activity in another area; 
b.  Limiting physical site access to established points of ingress and egress; and 
c.  Limiting the internal movement of vehicles and pedestrians to designed traffic configurations. 
E.  Stormwater management. 
1.  To encourage productive and enjoyable harmony between humans and nature; 
2.  To protect, restore, and maintain the chemical, physical and biological integrity of community waters; 
3.  To prevent individuals, business organizations and governments from causing harm to the community by activities which adversely affect water resources; 
4.  To encourage the construction of drainage systems which aesthetically and functionally approximate natural systems; 
5.  To encourage the protection of natural systems and the use of them in ways which do not impair their beneficial functioning; 
6.  To encourage the protection of natural systems which minimize the consumption of electrical energy or petroleum fuels to move water, remove pollutants, or maintain the system; 
7.  To minimize the transport of pollutants to community waters; 
8.  To maintain or restore groundwater levels; 
9.  To protect, maintain or restore natural salinity levels in estuarine areas; 
10.  To minimize erosion and sedimentation; 
11.  To discourage drainage of wetlands; 
12.  To prevent damage from flooding, while recognizing that natural fluctuations in water levels are beneficial; 
13.  To protect, restore, and maintain the habitat of fish and wildlife; and 
14.  To ensure the attainment of these objectives by requiring the approval and implementation of water management plans for all activities which may have a significant impact upon community waters. 
F.  Floodplain protection. 
1.  To protect human life and health. 
2.  To minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects. 
3.  To minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding and generally undertaken at public expense. 
4.  To minimize prolonged business interruptions and damage to public facilities and utilities caused by flooding. 
5.  To maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of flood-prone areas. 
6.  To ensure that potential purchasers of subdivided land are notified that the property is in a flood-prone area. 
7.  To assure that uses and facilities vulnerable to floods are designed and constructed to resist flood damage. 
8.  To preserve natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers to accommodate flood waters. 
9.  To limit filling, grading, dredging and other development which may increase erosion, sedimentation, or flood damage. 
10.  To prevent unnatural diversion of flood water to lands that are normally flood free. 
11.  To maintain the normal movement of surface waters, the optimum storage capacity of watersheds, desirable groundwater levels, water quality, and the natural hydrological and ecological functions of flood-prone lands. 
12.  To avoid the need of costly and environmentally disruptive flood management structures. 
13.  To encourage the use of flood-prone lands as open space. 
14.  To continue the city eligibility for participation in the National Flood Insurance Program. 
G.  Protection of environmentally sensitive lands/resources. 
1.  To protect environmentally sensitive lands and their beneficial functions while also protecting the rights of property owners. 
2.  To protect, maintain, and restore the chemical, physical, and biological integrity of ground and surface waters and natural habitats. 
3.  To prevent activities which adversely affect ground and surface waters, natural habitats, and native flora and fauna. 
4.  To prohibit certain uses that are detrimental to environmentally sensitive areas. 
5.  To protect the recreation opportunities of environmentally sensitive lands for fishing, boating, hiking, nature observations, photography, camping, and other uses. 
6.  To protect the public's rights in navigable waters. 
H.  Land and water use regulations. 
1.  To regulate the use of land and water for the use categories included in the South Daytona Comprehensive Plan as implemented through the zoning districts and official zoning map. 
2.  To provide for harmonious development of the city. 
3.  To encourage a high degree of quality and aesthetics in development. 
4.  To promote the public health, safety and welfare. 
I.  Concurrency management. To assure the appropriate provision of public facilities and services concurrent with the impacts of development based upon adopted levels-of-service. 
J.  Subdivision. To assure the proper legal description, identification, monumentation, and recording of real property; and, to assure that facilities and services which are dedicated to the public meet design, safety, health and regulatory standards and criteria. 
Sec. 1.6. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this Code shall apply to all development in the city occurring after the effective date hereof and no development shall be undertaken unless pursuant to this Code after said date, except for: 
A.  Any lawfully issued and effective development permit if: 
1.  The development authorized by the permit has been commenced prior to the effective date of this Code, or will be commenced after the effective date of this Code, but within six months of issuance of the building permit; and 
2.  The development continues without interruption until the development is complete. If the development permit expires, any further development on that site shall occur only in conformance with the requirements of this Code or any amendment thereto. 
B.  Developments with approved plans that have not expired at the time of adoption of this Code, or the adoption of any amendment thereto, and on which development has commenced or does commence, shall proceed according to the time limits in the regulations under which the development was originally approved. Such development must meet only the requirements of the regulations in effect when the development plan was approved. If the plan expires or is otherwise invalidated, any further development on that site shall occur only in conformity with the requirements of this Code or amendment thereto. 
Sec. 1.7. - Rules of interpretation. 
    In interpreting and applying this Code, all provisions shall be (1) considered as minimum requirements; (2) liberally construed in favor of the city, and; (3) deemed neither to limit nor repeal any other powers granted under law. 
ARTICLE II. - DEFINITIONS 

[Sec. 2.1.] - Interpretation of certain terms and words. 
    For the purpose of these land development regulations, certain terms or words used herein shall be interpreted as follows: 
    The present tense includes the future, the singular number includes the plural, and the plural number includes the singular. 
    The word person includes a firm, association, organization, governmental body, partnership, trust, company, or corporation as well as an individual. 
    The word shall is mandatory, and the word may is permissive. 
    The words used or occupied include the words arranged, designed, constructed, altered, converted, rented, leased, or intended to be used or occupied. 
    The word lot includes the words plot, parcel or tract. 
    The word structure includes the word building . 
    The word land includes the words water, marsh, or swamp. All words not defined in this Code shall carry their customary meaning as found in the most recent available edition of Webster's Dictionary. 
[Sec. 2.2. - Terms defined.] 
1.  Abandon means to cease from actively using a structure. In making the determination that a structure has been abandoned, the code enforcement official shall consider the existence or absence of a current local business tax receipt, utility service deposit or account, use of premises, and relocation of the use. 
2.  Abandoned personal property, abandoned articles means items of personal property, other than motor vehicles capable of being licensed under the laws of the state, which have been left unattended and unprotected from the elements; provided, however, that no such items located on private property shall be considered abandoned until they have been unattended and unprotected from the elements for a period of seven or more consecutive days. 
3.  Abandoned motor vehicle means any motor vehicle which is capable of being licensed under the laws of the State of Florida but which does not bear a current license plate; any motor vehicle which is not capable of being operated on public highways because of damage, disassembly or deterioration; provided, however, that no such motor vehicle located on private property shall be considered abandoned if the vehicle is in the process of being actively restored and is kept within a garage or similar enclosed structure and is concealed from public view. 
4.  Accessory living unit means a self-contained dwelling unit incorporated without substantial exterior alteration into the existing structure that was originally designed as a single-family dwelling. 
5.  Accessory use or structure means any use or detached structure customarily incidental and subordinate to the principal use or structure and located on the same lot with such principal use or structure. 
6.  Accommodation means any hotel, motel, tourist court, rooming house, or rental unit intended to be used for transient persons or tourists for overnight or temporary lodging. 
7.  Addition means any walled and roofed expansion to the perimeter of a building to which the addition is connected by a common load-bearing wall other than a fire wall. Any walled and roofed addition which is connected to the existing building by a fire wall or is separated from it by independent perimeter load-bearing walls is new construction. 
8.  Administrative official means the municipal official (or his authorized representative) appointed by the city manager to administer the land development regulations; this official is usually the community development director (CDD). 
9.  Adult congregate living facility means a residential building designed with individual or group sleeping quarters, with or without individual kitchen facilities, where common recreational, social, or dining facilities are also included. 
10.  Alley means any public or private right-of-way intended to be used as a secondary means of access for service to abutting properties and not intended for general traffic circulation. 
11.  Alteration means any change in a building's structural parts, stairways, type of construction, kind or class of occupancy, means of ingress and egress, wiring, plumbing, heating or cooling system, and other changes affecting or regulated by the building codes or this regulation, except for minor changes or repairs not involving the aforesaid features. The word alteration shall include words altered, repaired or reconstructed. 
12.  Amusement center means a building or site containing facilities for bowling, skating, miniature golf, video games, and similar recreation facilities designed for use by patrons of all ages; the term "amusement center" also includes within its meaning the terms "game room" and "recreation center." Besides the previously referenced activities, amusement center activities may also include the operation of machines which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc, may be operated by the public generally for use as a game, entertainment, or amusement, whether or not registering a score, including, but not limited to such devices as marble machines, pinball machines, skill ball, mechanical-grab machines, video-game machines, game-or-entertainment-simulation machines, and all games, operations or transactions similar thereto, under whatever name that may be indicated. 
12.5.  Antiques means items that are old, made or produced in the former period and have an estimated age of at least 100 years. Antiques inherently have a tendency to appreciate in value with age and may be represented in the form of furniture, glassware, art, guns, woodwork and other similar products. 
13.  Apartment means a dwelling unit constructed as part of a group of three or more dwelling units, which shares common structural members or facilities so as to preclude fee simple sale of individual units. 
14.  Apartment, garage means a detached accessory building containing both storage for one or more automobiles and single-family living quarters. 
15.  Aquifer means an underground formation, group of formations, or part of a formation that is permeable enough to transmit, store or yield usable quantities of water. 
16.  Area of special flood hazards means any area in the floodplain which is subject to a one percent chance of flooding annually, i.e., the 100-year flood, and which is designated as an area of special flood hazards on the FEMA Map. 
17.  Artificial drainage system means any canal, ditch, culvert, dike, storm sewer or other manmade facility which tends to control the surface flow of water. 
18.  Assured construction means construction improvements scheduled for public facilities in the Five-Year Schedule of Capital Improvements of the city, provided that the schedule is realistic, financially feasible, based upon currently available revenue sources, and contains targeted project commencement and completion dates. Actual construction will commence in or before the third year. 
19.  Automobile repair facility means a facility where major mechanical overhaul and repairs, paint and body work, and rebuilding of vehicle components is done. 
20.  Automobile service center means a business engaged in the servicing of motor vehicles allowing over the counter sale and installation of new or used replacement parts, equipment and accessories, including minor adjustments, tune-ups, wheel alignment and balancing, tire changing and repair, installation of exhaust system parts, brake linings, electrical repairs, and the like. All work shall be carried out within the sales building or service bays attached thereto. Specifically prohibited are engine rebuilding, body repair work or repainting, sale of vehicles or the outside storage of same, or the outside storage of parts and equipment other than for temporary display purposes. 
21.  Automobile service stations or filling stations means buildings and premises used for dispensing gasoline or other volatile fuel. Oil, grease, batteries, tires and automotive accessories may be supplied at retail, but are not required to meet this definition. Convenience stores shall not be included in this definition unless more than four pumps are available or the primary business purpose is the sale of volatile fuel. In addition, while not required to meet this definition, the following services may be rendered and sales made, and no other: 
a.  Sale and servicing of spark plugs, batteries, and distributor parts; 
b.  Tire servicing and repair, but not recapping or regrooving; 
c.  Replacement of mufflers and tail pipes, water hose, fan belts, brake fluid, light bulbs, fuses, floor mats, seat covers, windshield wipers and wiper blades, grease retainers, wheel bearings, mirrors, and the like; 
d.  Radiator cleaning and flushing; 
e.  Washing and polishing, and sale of automotive washing and polishing materials; 
f.  Greasing and lubrication; 
g.  Providing and repairing fuel pumps, oil pumps and lines; 
h.  Minor servicing and repair of carburetors; 
i.  Emergency wiring repairs; 
j.  Adjusting and repairing brakes; 
k.  Sales of cold drinks, packaged foods, tobacco, and similar convenience goods for service station customers, as accessory and incidental to principal operation; 
l.  Provision of road maps and other aforementioned material to customers; provision of restroom facilities. 
Uses permissible at a service station do not include major mechanical and body work, straightening of body parts, painting, welding, storage of automobiles not in operating condition or other work involving noise, glare, fumes, smoke, or other characteristics to an extent greater than normally found in service stations. A service station is neither a repair garage nor a body shop. 
22.  Automotive sales and service means the sale or storage of new automobiles, service stations and automobile service centers. 
23.  Available means a public facility or service shall be determined to be available for potable water, sanitary sewer, solid waste and storm drainage if it meets any of conditions one through three below. Park and recreation service shall be determined as available if any of conditions one through five are met. 
1.  The facility/service is in place to serve a proposed project at the time that a development order is approved; 
2.  The facility/service will be in place at the time of project impact; 
3.  The facility is under construction at the time that a development order is approved; 
4.  The facility/service is the subject of a binding executed construction contract at the time the development order is approved; 
5.  The facility/service is guaranteed through an enforceable development agreement. 
24.  Bar means an establishment devoted primarily to the retailing and drinking of malt, vinous, or other alcoholic beverages. The word bar shall include the words saloon, tavern, pub, barroom, cocktail lounge, bottle club and cabaret. 
25.  Basement means that portion of a building having its floor subgrade (below ground level) on all sides. 
26.  Board means any advisory board established by the City Council of the City of South Daytona, Florida. 
27.  Board of adjustments and appeals (BOAA) shall mean the board of adjustments and appeals as provided in this ordinance. 
28.  Boardinghouse means a building other than a hotel where lodging and meals for three or more non-related persons are furnished for compensation and where food is placed upon the table family-style without ordering individual portions from a menu. 
29.  Boathouse, private means an accessory building on the same lot as the residence or on a contiguous lot in the same ownership designed for the protection or storage of recreational watercraft only; such buildings may not be used for temporary or permanent dwelling purposes. 
29.5.  Body piercing establishment. An establishment whose principle business activity, either in terms of operation or held out the public, is the practice of penetrating the skin to make a hole, mark, or scar, generally permanent in nature. Does not include the use of a mechanized, pre-sterilized ear-piercing system that penetrates the outer perimeter or lobe of the ear or both. 
30.  Bufferyard/buffer area means a strip of land established to protect one type of land use from another with which it may be incompatible, and which may require the establishment of screening by fence, wall or natural growth. 
31.  Buildable area means that portion of a lot remaining after required yards (setbacks) have been provided. 
32.  Building cover, maximum (see Figure 2, Dimensional Requirements) means the greatest permitted amount of cumulative impervious surface that may be constructed or installed on a parcel of land, including e.g. building footprint, driveway, sidewalk, swimming pool, hard-surface parking, patio, shed pad, etc. 
33.  Building frontage means the side of the building meeting front setback requirements towards the principal road, street, highway or easement serving the building. 
34.  Building height means the vertical distance measured from the proposed or actual finished grade along the front of the building to the highest point of a flat roof, or to the deck line of a mansard roof, or to average height level between eaves and ridge for gable, hip, and gambrel roofs. 
35.  Building lines means the lines established by yard or setback requirements outside of which no principal building may be erected. 
36.  Building, principal means a structure in which the principal use on the lot is conducted. 
37.  Bulkhead line means a line established by city ordinance along the edge of a river, watercourse, or other body of water, in order to fix the maximum distance from the waters edge within which property improvements may be permitted. 
38.  Business services means those retail services customarily provided to commercial customers rather than general consumers, such as secretarial services, bookkeeping services, telephone answering services, mailing services, and the like. 
39.  Caliper means a minimum trunk diameter of replacement trees measured at a predetermined point of measurement. Trunk diameter for trees up to four inches in diameter is to be measured six inches above the soil line. All trees over four inches in diameter will be measured twelve inches above the soil line. 
40.  Carport means an accessory structure or portion of a principal structure consisting of a roof and supports and/or enclosed walls (except that at least one side is not enclosed) and designed or used for the storage of motor vehicles owned and used by the occupants of the building to which it is accessory. 
41.  Change of occupancy means a discontinuance of an existing use and the substitution of a different kind or class or use. Change of occupancy is not intended to include a change in tenants or proprietors unless accompanied by a change of use. 
42.  Chief building official or building official means the person or persons duly authorized by the City of South Daytona to be responsible for the administration and enforcement of the city's building codes. 
43.  Child care center means an establishment where five or more children, other than members of the immediate family occupying the premises, are cared for on a regular basis for compensation. The term includes child care center, day care center, day care agency, nursery school, play school, preschool, or any other terms denoting that children are under care for compensation. 
44.  Church means any building used for non-profit purposes by any duly constituted and legally established sect and primarily intended for use as a place of worship. Includes the term house-of-worship. 
45.  City means the City of South Daytona, Florida. 
46.  City council means the duly elected members of the City Council of the City of South Daytona, Florida. 
47.  City manager means the city manager of the City of South Daytona, or a person authorized to act in that capacity. 
48.  Clinic means an establishment where human patients, who are not lodged overnight, are admitted for examination and treatment by one or more persons practicing any form of healing arts, whether such persons be medical doctors, chiropractors, osteopaths, chiropodists, optometrists, dentists, or any such profession. 
49.  Club, night means a commercial establishment where alcoholic or other beverages may be obtained for consumption on the premises and where music and facilities for customer dancing are offered, and which may offer paid floor shows or other forms of paid entertainment to customers. 
50.  Club, private means an association or organization of a fraternal, social, or recreational character not operated or maintained for profit and incorporated under the laws of Florida as a nonprofit organization. 
51.  Cocktail lounge means the terms bar, tavern, and similar uses in which alcoholic beverages are sold for consumption on the premises, and in which no customer dancing or paid entertainment other than music is permitted. 
52.  Commercial vehicle means those vehicles used primarily for business purposes as indicated by signage on the vehicle, and used to transport or store business items in the provision of goods and services, regardless of size. Commercial vehicles include tow trucks, construction equipment, beach wagons, ice cream trucks, delivery trucks and similar vehicles. 
53.  Common facilities means common open space or common recreational facilities that are reserved primarily for the leisure and recreational use of the residents of a particular land development project, and are owned and maintained in common by the residents, or the project management. Common facilities may include outdoor recreation facilities such as swimming pools, sport courts, play apparatus and the like, and indoor facilities such as game rooms or club rooms. 
54.  Common open space means open space area, as defined by this regulation, that is in the common ownership of project residents. 
55.  Comprehensive plan means the official public master planning document on file in City Hall that has been adopted by the South Daytona City Council under the Growth Management Act of the State of Florida and is used to guide present and future land-use policy decisions. 
56.  Concept plan means an informal plan indicating the salient existing features of the site and its surroundings as described therein, and the general layout of a proposed subdivision or site development plan. 
57.  Concurrency or concurrent means that the public facilities and services necessary to maintain the adopted level-of-service standards are available when the impacts of development occur. 
58.  Concurrency compliance certification means the formal document issued by the city for a project after it has undergone a concurrency evaluation with a resultant finding of concurrency compliance. 
59.  Concurrency management system (CMS) means the procedures and process that the city utilizes to assure that development orders and permits, when issued, will not result in a reduction in levels-of-service below the adopted level-of-service standards in effect at the time of occurrence of the impacts of development. 
60.  Concurrency manager means the city manager or his designee who has the responsibility for ensuring that the CMS is implemented and operates effectively and as intended. At his option, the concurrency manager may delegate certain review and certification authority to other city staff. 
61.  Convenience grocery store means a retail outlet providing a limited line of food and household goods and designed for quick service to customers with small purchases. Type A provides for gasoline sales, and Type B prohibits gasoline sales. 
62.  Cul-de-sac means a street having one open end and being permanently terminated by a vehicular turn-around. 
63.  Dedication means deliberate appropriation of land by its owner for any general and public uses, reserving to the owner no other rights than those compatible with the full exercise and enjoyment of the public uses for which the property has been dedicated. 
64.  Density means the total number of dwelling units per gross acre of land. 
65.  Detention means the collection and storage of surface water for subsequent discharge. 
66.  Deteriorated means degenerated or damaged to the point where the death of the tree is imminent or to the point where the tree poses a significant hazard. 
67.  Developer means any person who acts in his own behalf or as the agent of an owner of property and engages in alteration of land or vegetation in preparation for construction activity. 
68.  [ Reserved. ] 
69.  Development means any significant manmade change to unimproved or improved real estate, including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavating or the permanent storage of materials. 
70.  Development order means any official city directive or determination which grants the issuance of a development permit or amendments thereto. 
71.  Development plan means a plan, which depicts the requirements specified in this Code, which may consist of several maps, data and other graphic and descriptive matter, for the physical development of land in the city including any amendments, extensions or additions thereto adopted by the city. 
72.  Development review committee (DRC) means the staff committee assigned the function of reviewing and recommending development orders in the city. 
73.  Diameter at breast height (DBH) means the diameter, in inches, of a tree measured at four and one-half feet above the existing grade. 
74.  Discharge means the outflow of water from a project, site, aquifer, drainage basin or facility. 
75.  Drainage system or natural drainage system means surface streams or swamps which convey water to natural points of discharge. 
76.  Drip line means a perpendicular line that extends downward from the outermost tips of the tree branches to the ground. 
77.  Dwelling means any building or part thereof with cooking facilities and occupied in whole or in part as the residence or living quarters of one or more persons, permanently, temporarily or transiently. The word dwelling shall not include the words hotel, motel, tourist court, boardinghouse, travel trailer, cabins, or tents. The general term dwelling does not include those structures defined as mobile homes. 
78.  Dwelling unit means a room or rooms connected together to form a separate and independent housekeeping establishment to be occupied by one family and containing sleeping facilities, sanitary facilities, and kitchen. 
79.  Dwelling, multiple-family means a building containing three or more dwelling units. 
80.  Dwelling, single-family detached means one dwelling on its own lot which is entirely surrounded by open space and not attached to another dwelling unit. 
81.  Dwelling, single-family attached means a dwelling unit on its own lot with its own entry and yard areas, that is physically attached to one or more dwellings by a common wall or roof structure. 
82.  Dwelling, two-family means a building containing only two dwelling units. 
83.  Easement means a right-of-way or access granted for limited use of private property for a public or quasi-public or private purpose. 
84.  Elevated building means a non-basement building built to have the lowest floor elevated above the ground level by means of fill, solid foundation perimeter walls, pilings, columns (posts and piers), shear walls, or breakaway walls. 
85.  Encroachment means any protrusion of a structure, vehicle or use into an area where it is not ordinarily allowed under this Code. This includes any protrusion of a vehicle outside of a parking space, display area or accessway into a landscaped area. 
86.  Enforcement official means the city manager or designee who is responsible for enforcing the provisions of the land development regulations. 
87.  Erect means to build, construct, attach, hang, place, suspend or affix, and shall also include the painting of wall signs. 
88.  Existing means the average condition immediately before development or redevelopment commences. 
89.  Expansion of existing mobile home parks means the construction of facilities, including concrete pads, if any, or if no such pads are to be provided, then the installation of utilities and final site grading, started after July 23, 1976, in a mobile home park existing on July 23, 1976. "Expansion of mobile home parks" shall not include the rental, sale, or lease of any mobile home space or site which is ready for use or occupancy on July 23, 1976, and is located within a mobile home park existing on July 23, 1976. 
90.  Facing or surface means the surface of a sign upon, against or through which the message is displayed or illustrated on the sign. 
91.  Family means one or more persons all living together and related by blood, marriage, or legal adoption, and occupying the same dwelling unit. Two people living together as a single housekeeping unit though not related by blood, adoption or marriage shall constitute a family for the purposes of this Code. 
92.  Finger means a manmade portion of land nearly surrounded by water, consisting of a roadway ending in a cul-de-sac and lots on both sides of the road, and where the lots abut the roadway and the water. 
93.  Finished grade means the completed surface of lawns, walks and driveways brought to grade as shown on building/construction plans or designs relating thereto. 
94.  Flood or flooding means: 
(a)  A general and temporary condition of partial and complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow of inland or tidal water, or from the unusual and rapid accumulation of run-off of surface waters form any source. 
(b)  The collapse or subsidence of land along the shore of a lake or other body of water as a result of erosion or undermining caused by waves or currents of water exceeding anticipated cyclical levels or suddenly caused by an unusually high water level in a natural body of water, accompanied by a severe storm or force of nature, such as a flash flood or an abnormal tidal surge, or by some similarly unusual event which results in flooding as defined above. 
95.  Floodplain means any normally dry land area that is susceptible to being inundated by waters of the one percent annual chance flood, i.e., the 100-year flood. 
96.  Floodproofing means a combination of structural and/or nonstructural additions, changes or adjustments to properties or structures subject to flooding which will reduce or eliminate flood damages to properties, water and sewer facilities, structures and contents of buildings. 
97.  Floodway means the channel of a river or other watercourse and the adjacent land areas that must be reserved in order to discharge the velocity waters of the regulatory flood. 
98.  Floor area ratio means total floor area of all buildings on a lot divided by the gross area of the lot. 
99.  Floor area means the sum of the gross horizontal areas of the several floors of a building measured from the exterior faces of the exterior walls or from the centerline of walls separating two buildings; excluding garages, attic areas of fire escapes, elevator structures, cooling towers, areas devoted to air conditioning, ventilating, or heating or other building machinery and equipment, porches, patios, or breezeways. 
100.  For sale means an offer to sell conveyed by means of signage, written or oral representations, or offers to sell, or inclusion of an item on a written inventory of items for sale. 
101.  Functionally dependent facility means a facility which cannot be used for its intended purpose unless it is located or carried out in close proximity to water, such as a docking or port facility necessary for the loading and unloading of cargo or passengers, shipbuilding, ship repair, or seafood processing facilities. The term does not include long-term storage, manufacture, sales, or service facilities. 
102.  Funeral home means a building used for the preparation of the deceased for burial and the display of the deceased and ceremonies connected therewith before burial or cremation. 
103.  Garbage and trash enclosure means the structure surrounding the garbage and trash storage facility including but not limited to fences and walls. 
104.  Garbage and trash storage facilities means the container for holding refuse, trash or garbage including but not limited to dumpsters, garbage cans, recycling containers and garbage bags or boxes. 
105.  Groundwater means water beneath the surface of the ground whether or not flowing through known and definite channels. 
106.  Guest house means a detached accessory building located on the premises with the principal building for use by temporary guests or domestic help of the occupants of the premises; such building shall not contain kitchen facilities and shall not be rented or used as a separate dwelling. 
107.  Heating and air conditioning use means use of water for heating, cooling, or air-conditioning. 
108.  Historic tree means a tree which has been found by a professional forester, horticulturist, or other professional plantsman, to be of notable historic interest to South Daytona or Volusia County because of its age, type, size or historic association and has been so recognized by the City of South Daytona. 
109.  Home occupation is an occupation conducted entirely in a residential dwelling unit subject to the provisions of this land development code. 
110.  Hotel means a building or group of buildings in which sleeping accommodations are offered for rental primarily for transients, and which has the primary means of access to the sleeping rooms through an inside lobby. 
111.  Hydrograph means a graph of discharge versus time for a selected outfall point. 
112.  Hydrologic cycle means the movement of water through the environment on, above and below the surface of the earth. 
113.  Industrial park means a special or exclusive type of planned industrial area designed and equipped to accommodate a community of compatible industries and allied uses providing them with all necessary facilities and services. 
114.  Industry means any activity involving the manufacturing or treatment of any commodity, including the assembly, packaging, canning, bottling, or processing of any items. To change any commodity in composition, form size, shape, texture, or appearance is deemed to be an industrial process. The word industry shall include the word manufacture. 
115.  Junk yard means a lot or land area where used or second hand materials are bought, sold, exchanged, stored, baled, packaged, packed, disassembled, or handled, including but not limited to scrap iron and other metals, cloths, paper, rags, plumbing fixtures, rubber tires, bottles. The words "junk yard" include the words "automobile wrecking yard" and "salvage operation" or "salvage yard." 
116.  Kindergarten. See child care center. 
117.  Land means the earth, water, air, above, below or on the surface, and includes any vegetation, improvements or structures customarily regarded as land. 
118.  Land clearing/alteration means the removal of any tree or brush or the moving of terrain, except mowing. 
119.  Land development regulation board (LDRB) means the duly appointed members of the land development regulation board of the City of South Daytona, Florida, also referred to as the LDRB, having the powers and duties set forth in this Code. 
120.  Land development regulations (LDR's) or Code means a unified body of codes duly adopted and enacted by the city council to regulate all development and construction activities in South Daytona. The word "Code" as used herein shall mean the " LDR's." 
121.  Landscape irrigation use means outside watering or sprinkling of shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, ground cover, plants, vines, gardens and other such flora which are planted and established and are situated in such diverse locations as residential landscaping, recreation areas, cemeteries, public, commercial and industrial establishments, public medians and rights-of-way. 
122.  Level-of-service standard (LOSS) means the benchmark indicator of the extent or degree of service provided by a facility and which has been adopted in the comprehensive plan or subsequent amendments as a minimum acceptable level. 
123.  Living area means that area of a dwelling unit, enclosed, which is protected from the elements and heated, including interior halls, closets, utility and storage areas, but excluding garages, carports, screened porches, unenclosed and unheated areas, and cellars. 
124.  Living unit means a room or rooms comprising the essential elements of a single housekeeping unit. Facilities for the preparation, storage, and keeping of food for consumption within the premises shall cause a unit to be construed as a living unit. Bath facilities may not be private for the living unit, but shall be accessible to the living unit. 
125.  Lot means a tract or parcel of land identified as a single unit in a subdivision and intended for transfer of ownership, use or improvement. 
(1)  Lot depth. A distance measured in the mean direction of the sidelines of the lot from the midpoint of the front lot line to the midpoint of the opposite main rear line of the lot. 
(2)  Lot width. The mean horizontal distance between the side lines measured at right angles to the depth at the front building line. 
126.  Lot classification, for the purpose of this land development Code, lots shall be classified as corner lots, interior lots, and through lots. 
127.  Lot, corner (corner lot) means a lot located at the intersection of two more streets. A lot abutting a curved street or streets shall be considered a corner lot if straight lines drawn from the foremost points of the side lot lines to the foremost point of the lot meet at an interior angle of less than 135 degrees. 
128.  Lot coverage means that portion of the lot that is covered by buildings and structures, and does not include parking, sidewalks, or other paved or hard surface. 
129.  Lot frontage shall be construed as that side of a lot which fronts upon the primary vehicular accessway, be it a public or private road or drive. 
130.  Lot, interior (interior lot) means a lot other than a corner lot with only one frontage on a street. 
131.  Lot line, front means any property line that adjoins a travelled way. The primary front lot line is that street frontage on which the address is given. 
132.  Lot line, rear means the property line internal to a block that is most distant from and most nearly parallel to the primary front lot line. On corner lots, a property owner may choose one of the front lot lines to determine which internal lot line(s) shall serve as the rear lot line. 
133.  Lot lines means the property lines bounding the lot. 
134.  Lot line, side means any property that is interior to a block and is not considered to be a rear property line. A side lot line which is adjacent to a street right-of-way is considered a corner side lot line and may be regulated differently from an interior side lot line. 
135.  Lot, non-conforming means any lot which does not meet the minimum dimensions, area, or other regulations of the district in which the lot is located. This classification includes all sub-standard lots. 
136.  Lot of record means a lot whose existence, location and dimensions have been legally recorded or registered in a deed or on a plat, either prior to the effective date of this ordinance, or after the effective date of this ordinance. 
137.  Lot, split means the division of a lot or lot of record into a maximum of two lots. 
138.  Lot, through means a lot other than a corner lot with frontage on more than one street. Through lots abutting two streets are also referred to as double frontage lots. 

139.  Low-volume irrigation means the use of equipment and devices specifically designed to limit the volume of water delivered to a level consistent with the water requirement of the plant being irrigated and to allow that water to be placed with a high degree of efficiency in the root zone of the plant. 
140.  Low-volume pressure cleaning means pressure cleaning by means of equipment which is specifically designed to reduce the inflow volume as accepted by industry standards. 
141.  Lowest floor (including basement) means any floor used for living, which includes working, sleeping, eating, cooking or recreation facilities, or any combination thereof. 
142.  Major recreational equipment (MRE) means motorized equipment or equipment customarily towed behind motor vehicles, such as boats and boat trailers, travel trailers, pick-up campers or coaches, motorized dwelling and tent trailers. This term also includes recreational vehicles, plus accessory equipment. 
143.  Manufactured building means a building that is: 
1.  Mass-produced in a factory; 
2.  Designed and constructed for transportation to a site for installation and use when connected to required utilities; 
3.  Either an independent, individual building or a module for combination with other elements to form a building on the site; and 
4.  Erected on a permanent foundation. 
144.  Manufactured home means: 
1.  A structure, transportable on one or more sections, which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities; 
2.  A manufactured building or portion of a building designed for long-term residential use and regulated by the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). 
145.  Manufactured housing subdivision means a subdivision of land recorded in the office of the Circuit Court of Volusia County, Florida, designed for use by mobile homes, the lots of which are individually owned. 
146.  Mean sea level means the average height of the sea for all stages of the tide. 
146.5.  Mini-storage. A mini-storage facility in a building consisting of individual self-contained units of varying size that are leased or owned for the storage of business and household goods, or for contractor's supplies. This category includes use types providing individual, self-contained units or areas leased to individuals, organizations, or businesses for self-service storage of household and personal property, business goods and contractor supplies. The storage units or areas are designed to allow private access by the tenant or owner for storing or removing personal property. Use of the storage areas for sales, service, repair, or manufacturing operations is not considered accessory to self-service storage. Occupancy of the storage area other than for pick-up or dropping-off items that are stored is prohibited. 
147.  Mobile home means a manufactured home built on a chassis. A mobile home shall be constructed to remain a mobile home, subject to all regulations applying thereto, whether or not wheels, axles, hitch, or other appurtenances of mobility are removed and regardless of the nature of the foundation provided. A mobile home shall not be construed to be a travel trailer or other form of recreational vehicle. 
148.  Mobile home park means a parcel (or continuous parcels) of land which has been so designated and improved that it contains two or more mobile home lots available to the general public for rent or sale and the placement thereon of mobile homes for occupancy. 
149.  Mobile home subdivision means an area of land duly platted in accordance with the provision of this Code, which contains manufactured housing and is designed with all improvements specified and installed pursuant to these regulations. Only one mobile home containing a single-family dwelling unit shall be permitted on each lot. (Units require an RP tag). 
150.  Motel means a building or a group of buildings in which sleeping accommodations are offered for rental primarily to transients and customarily having individual access from the units to the parking lot. 
151.  Motor vehicle means an automobile, motorcycle, travel trailer, a truck, or van, or similar conveyance propelled by a motor. 
152.  Motor vehicle wrecking means the dismantling or disassembling of motor vehicles or the storage, sale or dumping of dismantled, partially dismantled, obsolete or wrecked vehicles. 
153.  Natural flow pattern means the rate, volume, and direction of the surface or groundwater flow occurring under natural conditions for any given portion of Volusia County. 
154.  New construction (for flood control/FEMA purposes) means those structures the construction or substantial improvement of which is begun after July 23, 1976. New construction, for purposes of this section, shall also mean those mobile homes within mobile home parks for which construction has started after July 23, 1976, and which are located within a new mobile home park, or expansion of an existing mobile home park where repair, construction or improvement of streets, utilities and/or pads equals or exceeds 50 percent of the fair market value of the streets, utilities and pads before the repair, reconstruction or improvement has commenced. 
155.  No tree verification means a signed notarized statement by an owner or his agent stating that no trees exist upon the site. 
156.  Non-conforming building/structure means a building or structure which does not conform to the regulations for the district in which it is located. 
157.  Non-conforming use of land means the use of land for other than a use specifically permitted in the zoning district in which the land is located. 
158.  Nursing home means an extended or intermediate-care facility licensed by the state to provide full-time convalescent or chronic care to individuals who, by reason of advanced age, chronic illness or infirmity, are unable to care for themselves. 
159.  Official zoning map means the current official zoning map of the City of South Daytona, Florida. 
160.  Open space means that portion of a development project that is not occupied by buildings, pavements, or other impervious surfaces, or is not intended in the future to be occupied by impervious surfaces. Open space is specifically defined as 50 percent of the area of manmade water bodies, 75 percent of the natural open water bodies, and 100 percent of wetland areas subject to intermittent flooding. 
161.  Owner or property-owner means the owner of property. 
161.5.  Permanent make-up services. Permanent makeup is synonymous with cosmetic tattooing and includes the application of permanent eyeliner, eyebrows, full lip color, re-pigmentation or camouflage using tattooing techniques of placing pigments under the skin. 
162.  Permit or development permit means any official city authorizing act allowing a physical land development activity, including any building permit, zoning permit, subdivision approval, special use, special exception, variance or other action having the effect of permitting the development of land, except for those actions, particularly for certain types of building permits, which do not result in any increased impact on the levels-of-service of public facilities. 
163.  Person means any and all persons, natural or artificial and includes any individual, firm, corporation, government agency, business trust, estate, trust, partnership, association, two or more persons having a joint or common interest, or any other legal entity. 
164.  Personal services means a beauty parlor, shop, or salon, barber shop, massage, reducing or slenderizing studio, steam or turkish bath, etc. 
165.  Planned unit development means a tract of land to be planned and developed in accord with comprehensive and detailed plans and regulations as required in the PUD Zoning District. 
166.  Premises means a lot or lots together with all buildings and structures thereon, that function(s) as a unified residential, commercial or industrial entity. 
167.  Principal use means the main or primary purpose for which a structure or lot is designed, arranged, or intended or for which they may be used, occupied, or maintained under this Code. 
168.  Professional office means an office for the conduct of business in any of the following or related categories: law, architecture, city planning, engineering, land surveying, medicine, dentistry, osteopathy, chiropractic, opticians, accounting or consultants in these or related fields. 
169.  Protective barrier means a physical structure limiting access to a protected area. 
170.  Public facilities means the six types of critical public facilities and services denoted by the following terms: potable water, sanitary sewer, solid waste, parks and recreation, drainage, and roadways. 
171.  Public right-of-way means and includes any right-of-way, easement or other pathway over the land vested in and used for the benefit of the general public, whether by dedication or prescription, and irrespective of ownership or control being vested in some entity other than the City of South Daytona, so long as the public right-of-way is included within the corporate limits of the city. 
172.  Public use means a use of any land, water, or buildings by a municipality, public body or board, commission or authority, franchised utility, county, state or federal government or any agency thereof for a public service or purpose. 
173.  Quasi-public means use or semi-public use of any land, water, or buildings by a non-profit organization or company for a public service or purpose. 
174.  Receiving bodies of water means any waterbodies, watercourses or wetlands into which surface waters flow. 
175.  Recharge means the inflow of water into a site aquifer, drainage basin or facility. 
176.  Reclaimed (reuse) water means the water that meets the current Florida Department of Environmental Regulation standards for reuse after flowing out of any treatment plant or works. 
177.  Recreational vehicle means a vehicle, except a vehicle prohibited under Article VII, section 9.0, Subsection (Miscellaneous Parking Regulations) in paragraph (A) of this Code, designed and used primarily for temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, or travel use, whether or not such vehicle is self-propelled or is mounted on or drawn by another vehicle or other power sources. The term "designed" means that the interior space of the vehicle is designed and used for temporary living human occupancy with characteristics such as, for example, a kitchen, a bathroom, a sleeping area, a furnished resting area, etc. The term "living quarters" does not include the ordinary driver/passenger compartment of the vehicle or areas for storage of such equipment as bicycles, go-carts, or motorcycles. 
178.  Regulatory flood elevation means the crest elevation in relation to mean sea level expected to be reached by the regulatory flood at any given point in an area of special flood hazard as regulated by and shown on the FEMA map. 
179.  Regulatory flood means a flood event having a one percent chance of occurring in any given year, although the flood may occur in any year, i.e., the 100-year flood as defined by FEMA. 
180.  Replacement tree means any immature tree having an overall caliper of at least two inches. 
181.  Replacing means rebuilding, enlarging or any change in size, structure or lettering other than repainting and repair to electrical, mechanical or plumbing apparatus. 
182.  Restaurant means a building or room where meals are prepared and food, including beverages and confections, is served to customers. Restaurants are hereby classified as follows: 
Type A: Restaurants with dining tables and counter stools having all service indoors and providing no service to persons inside vehicles or at walk-up windows. 
Type B: Any restaurant serving food and/or beverages to persons in their vehicles for consumption therein, commonly referred to as "drive-in" restaurants. 
Type C: Restaurant which provides outdoor seating as part of its normal operations. 
183.  Retail sales, general means those sales of products and services that are customarily required by the average homeowner, and oriented to home use and consumption. 
184.  Retention means the collection and storage of runoff not designed for subsequent discharge to surface waters. 
185.  Reuse means the deliberate application of reclaimed water for beneficial uses such as landscape irrigation, agricultural irrigation, aesthetic uses, ground water recharge, industrial uses, fire protection, etc. 
186.  School means any building or part thereof which is designed, constructed or used for educational instruction. 
187.  Sediment facility means any structure or area which is designed to hold runoff water until suspended sediments have settled. 
188.  Sediment means fine particulate material, whether mineral or organic, that is in suspension or has settled in a waterbody. 
189.  Setback lines means the lines established by yard or setback requirements outside of which no principal building may be erected. Includes building lines. 
190.  Shopping center means a group of commercial establishments planned, developed, owned, or managed as a unit. 
191.  Sidewalk means any portion of a public or private right-of-way between the curb line and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways, or that portion of the public or private right-of-way paved or otherwise improved and intended for pedestrian traffic. 
192.  Sight distance means the minimum extent of unobstructed forward vision (in a horizontal plane) along a street from a vehicle located at any given point on the street. 
193.  Sign. Note that all sign definitions are found in the sign Code (Section 8.2 of Article VIII). 
194.  Site means any tract, lot or parcel of land or combination of thereof, which is/are in one ownership, or are contiguous and in diverse ownership where development is to be performed as part of a unit, subdivision, or project. 
195.  Site plan means "development plan". 
196.  Special exception means a use that would not be appropriate generally or without restriction throughout the zoning district, but which, if controlled as to number, area, location, or relation to the neighborhood, would promote the public health, safety, and general welfare. Such uses may be permitted in a zoning district as a special exception only if specific provision therefor is made in this Code. 
197.  Special use means a use or occupancy of a property not otherwise permitted outright or by special exception in its zoning classification, but which, due to unique conditions, may be deemed appropriate by the city council, within the intent of this land development regulation to protect the public health, safety, and general welfare of the city and its residents. A special use may be limited as to duration, design, hours of operation, or in any other way deemed necessary within the intent of the Code. 
198.  Specimen tree means a tree which has been determined to be of high value because of its size, type, age or other criteria as determined by the City of South Daytona. 
The following species of trees with the minimum specified DBH are determined to be specimen trees in Volusia County, Florida:
