    A non-conforming structure existing prior to the adoption of this Code shall continue to have such non-conforming status and shall be subject to the applicable provisions of this Code, including the following, which shall apply so long as the use of land or structure remains otherwise lawful: 
1.  No such non-conforming structure may be enlarged or altered in a way which increases its nonconformity, but any structure or portion thereof may be altered to decrease its non-conformity. 
2.  Should such non-conforming structure or non-conforming portion of structure be destroyed by any means to an extent of more than 50 percent of its current assessed value as recorded in the Volusia County Property Appraiser's office at the time of destruction, it shall not be reconstructed except in conformity with the provisions of this Code. 
3.  Should such structure be moved for any reason for any distance whatever, it shall thereafter conform to the regulations of the district in which it is located after it is removed. 
E.  Non-conforming mobile home uses and structures. 
1.  In a mobile home park or a mobile home subdivision which constitutes a non-conforming use or contains non-conforming structures and the non-conformity cannot be completely corrected, a mobile home may be replaced if the replacement mobile home complies with the current front, side and rear yard setbacks as required for the intended location or, if it cannot meet the setback requirements, the replacement mobile home is equipped with an automatic fire sprinkler system sufficient to meet city standards. 
2.  The city shall waive the plumbing and electrical permit fees for any individual who elects to have the replacement mobile home equipped with an automatic fire sprinkler system as set forth in paragraph (1) above. 
3.  A mobile home which constitutes a non-conforming use that is located on property other than in a mobile home park or mobile home subdivision cannot be replaced once the mobile home is removed from its location. 
4.  Except as specifically provided in this section, mobile home parks and mobile home subdivisions which are either non-conforming uses or contain non-conforming structures shall be governed by the regulations and restrictions as set forth in the non-conforming provisions of the land development code or as set forth by statutory or case law. 
F.  Repairs and maintenance. On any non-conforming structure or portion of a structure containing a non-conforming use, repairs and modernization are permitted provided that the cubic area existing when it became non-conforming shall not be increased. Nothing in this Code shall be deemed to prevent the strengthening or restoring to a safe condition of any building or part thereof declared to be unsafe by any public official charged with protecting the public safety, upon order of such official. 
G.  Abandonment of non-conforming uses of land or structures. If a non-conforming use of land or a non-conforming use of structure has been abandoned for a period of 180 consecutive days, such use shall not thereafter be re-established and any future use shall be in conformity with the provisions of this Code. 
H.  All appurtenances, including but not limited to curb/gutter, roadways, utilities, stormwater management features, etc., shall be brought into conformance upon conversion, maintenance or improvement valued at 50 percent of the value of the appurtenance. 
I.  Uses under special exception or special use provisions are not non-conforming uses. Any use which is permitted as a special exception or special (conditional) use in a district under the terms of this Code shall be deemed a conforming use, subject to any conditions legally imposed by the city council in the past. 
J.  Non-conforming uses/structures in flood hazard areas. A structure or the use of a structure or premises which was lawful before the passage or amendment of this article but which is not in conformity with its provisions may be continued as a non-conforming use subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Any substantial improvement of a non-conforming structure shall be made in compliance with the provisions of this Code. 
2.  If such use is discontinued for 90 consecutive days, any future use of the building premises shall conform to this Code. 
3.  If any non-conforming use or structure is destroyed by any means, including floods, to an extent of 50 percent or more of its assessed value immediately prior to the destruction, it shall not be reconstructed except in conformity with the provisions of this Code. 
4.  The value of all improvements, modifications, additions, and reconstruction to any existing building in the flood hazard area shall be recorded and counted cumulatively for ten years from the first date of such action. When the cumulative total value of such improvements exceeds 50 percent of the assessed value of such building, it shall be brought up to the code requirements for new buildings. 
K.  Conversions to condominiums. It is hereby declared that the conversion of an apartment, hotel or motel into a condominium shall constitute a change in use and as such the grandfathered status of all nonconformities shall terminate. 
(Ord. No. 97-23, § 1, 12-9-97; Ord. No. 05-23, § 1, 7-12-05; Ord. No. 06-12, § 1, 6-13-06) 
Sec. 3.14. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-16, § 1, adopted August 28, 2007, repealed § 3.14, which pertained to general development agreements. See also the Land Development Code Comparative Table. 
ARTICLE IV. - CONSISTENCY AND CONCURRENCY 

Sec. 4.1. - Consistency. 
    This Code and all development constructed subsequent to the adoption of the comprehensive plan must be consistent with the plan. To that end, this section of the Code establishes consistency requirements. 
A.  Consistency of land development regulations. It is hereby determined and declared that the provisions of this Code implement the goals, objectives and policies of the South Daytona Comprehensive Plan. 
B.  Development consistent with Code. After adoption of the South Daytona Comprehensive Plan, all developments approved thereafter must be consistent with the plan. In addition, development must conform with the terms and conditions outlined in this Code. 
1.  Consistency checklist. As a prerequisite to the issuance of a development order/permit under this Code, the director shall be responsible for reviewing and approving a consistency checklist to determine whether or not the proposed order/permit and development activity is consistent with the comprehensive plan and this Code. The checklist may be made prior to the submission or at the time of submission of an application for development permit. 
2.  Procedure if inconsistent. If it is determined that the proposed development order would result in an inconsistency with the Comprehensive Plan and Code the following actions may occur: 
a.  The director may approve the proposed development with conditions necessary to bring the application/request into conformance with the plan and Code; or 
b.  The director may initiate an amendment, pursuant to this Code, in order to facilitate a determination of consistency for a development permit, when it is found that such amendment would not affect the intent, character, and public interest as determined by the Comprehensive Plan or this Code. 
Sec. 4.2. - Concurrency management system. 
A.  Purpose. The purpose of the concurrency management system (CMS) described herein is to enable the city to comply with section 163.3202 (g) of the "Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act," Chapter 163, Part II, F.S., which requires: "that the city implement local land development regulations which provide that public facilities and services meet or exceed the standards established in the capital improvements element of the comprehensive plan and are available when needed to meet the impacts of development, and that not later than one year after the official due date of the city's comprehensive plan, the city shall not issue a development order or permit resulting in a reduction in the level-of-service (LOS) for affected public facilities below the level-of-service adopted by the comprehensive plan. The city also intends that the CMS be consistent with Rule 9J-5.0055 F.A.C. which provides guidelines to local governments for the preparation and implementation of a CMS which will ensure the availability of public facilities and services concurrent with the impacts of development. To ensure that facilities and services needed to support development are available concurrent with the impacts of such development, a local government must adopt a concurrency management system." 
    The city's concurrency management system shall measure the potential impact of any proposed development upon the levels-of-service for potable water, sanitary sewer, solid waste, parks and recreation, drainage, and roadways by comparing that impact with available capacity and the city's adopted level-of-service standards for those public facilities. No final development permit shall be approved unless the city has determined, through the use of this mechanism, that adequate public facilities will be available at the time of project impact. 
B.  Intent. The city intends that the CMS be functionally compatible with the city's character as an already substantially built-out municipality, with virtually no potential for urban sprawl, within a surrounding urban core. This means that virtually all new development may be characterized as "in-fill," and its impact on facility levels-of-service should be relatively minor. 
    The city intends that the concurrency management system provide the basic principles and guidelines for its implementation. However, it is not the intent of the city that the ordinance contain all of the detailed administrative procedures required for the day-to-day operation of the program. Instead, the city desires that city officials responsible for the CMS possess a certain degree of flexibility and latitude to develop and employ such additional procedures, forms, etc. as they deem necessary for carrying out an effective and efficient concurrency management system. The city manager may develop as an administrative policy a concurrency manual or guide to assist city officials in the day-to-day administration of the program; such a document would provide more detail than the ordinance concerning administrative procedures. 
    It is not the intent of the city that the concurrency management system in any of its aspects, including concurrency evaluation and the issuance of concurrency compliance determinations, replace any other development review criteria used by the city, unless those criteria are inconsistent with the provisions of the concurrency management ordinance. The CMS is designed to primarily complement and not to replace the other review criteria. 
C.  Basic principles. 
1.  The CMS will formally take effect on the date specified in the adopting ordinance. 
2.  Each year in September, the city shall verify by capacity reservation certifications from the following provider entities for the public facilities indicated: City of Daytona Beach-potable water and sanitary sewer; Volusia County-solid waste. These statements shall cover at least the fiscal year starting October 1, and the five-year period starting with that fiscal year. 
3.  Each year in September, the city shall issue its own capacity reservation certifications to cover the succeeding fiscal year and the following four fiscal years (a total of five fiscal years) for the following public facilities: roadways, parks and recreation. 
4.  Each year in September, the city shall issue its own drainage certification to cover the succeeding fiscal year and the following four fiscal years (a total of five fiscal years) to cover on-site drainage facilities. 
5.  Concurrency review for a specific project will begin at the time of application for development approval. A determination of concurrency will be made at the time the application is submitted. Once capacity has been determined to be available, this capacity will be reserved and ultimately a capacity award will be made based on the Table 1 presented in Section C.7. 
6.  For each development application a concurrency compliance review form (CCRF) shall be completed, processed and filed (See Figure 4.) 
7.  The concurrency compliance review form establishes the service capacity reserved for that project. This capacity is reserved for the time period shown on the following chart. When a final development order is issued, this reservation shall be awarded through the issuance of a concurrency compliance certification. This certification shall remain valid for the time period shown on the following chart. If a capacity reservation cannot be made for one or more critical facilities, a concurrency compliance certification shall not be issued for the project. For those projects requiring several approvals, the reservation of capacity may occur at a different time than the final award of capacity. 
Table 1 
South Daytona Development Capacity Management Process 
Capacity 
Reservation Reservation 
Expiration Capacity 
Award Capacity 
Expiration Building Permit Approval by CBO 2 months Issuance and delivery 6 months Subdivision Approval LDRB concept plat approval 12 months City council final plat approval 24 months Site Plan Approval DRC review 6 months DRC approval 12 months  
8.  Impacts of phased projects shall be evaluated based on the phased development schedule. Capacity reservations and approvals may only be given for those phases occurring within the capital facilities horizon, and capacity awards may only be given as set forth in Section C.7 above. 
D.  Criteria for concurrency evaluation of public facilities. The following criteria will be used in conjunction with the concurrency compliance review form to evaluate the impact of proposed projects on public facilities. It should be noted, however, that for selected public facilities-i.e. potable water, sanitary sewer, and solid waste-overall city-wide demand (needed capacity) will be calculated based upon population estimates and projections generated annually by the Bureau of Economic and Business Research of the University of Florida (BEBR). This calculation will be done once per year (in September) by multiplying the given population level for a particular target year by the adopted level-of-service standard (a per capita figure); then the city-wide demand will be compared with the reserved capacity allocated by the provider for the period in question; if the city-wide demand is less than the available capacity, there shall be no adverse impact on the LOSS-i.e. there shall be no concurrency problem or deficiency. Even in these cases, however, project-by-project impact shall be calculated, evaluated, recorded and tracked to assure that the actual cumulative demand/impact does not exceed the available capacity for any relevant time period; the use of the CCRF form is essential for this process. 
1.  Roadway facilities. 
a.  Roadway capacity will be evaluated using the Florida Highway System Plan Level-of-Service Standards and Guidelines issued by FDOT and effective Jan. 1, 1989 (and as subsequently modified). Traffic modeling, when required, shall use the FSUTMS model. 
b.  Properties serviced by local roadways located within a recorded subdivision plat will be evaluated for impact at the nearest point of ingress/egress to the roadway network. 
c.  The impact on the roadway system will be determined by using the trip-generation standards contained in the VOLUSIA COUNTY IMPACT FEE ORDINANCE #86-6, as amended. The estimated trips generated by the proposed project will be subtracted cumulatively from the available capacity on the roadway to determine whether roadway capacity is adequate to support the project based upon the resultant LOS in comparison with the city's adopted LOSS for the roadway in question. 
d.  If no official traffic count exists for a collector or arterial, the city will provide the count within a reasonable period, unless it is arranged for by the applicant. If the city provides the count, the cost may be passed on to the applicant. 
e.  Calculation of total traffic to be generated by a proposed project will assume 100 percent build-out and occupancy. Credits against the trips generated by non-residential land uses will be applied using the percentages employed by the Volusia County Impact Fee System. Any claimed credit for capture of trips from passing traffic in excess of these percentages must be justified by the applicant. Any claimed credit for internal absorption of trips for a mixed-use development must also be justified by the applicant. 
f.  Proposed development which generates 100 or fewer average daily trips shall not be subject to an individual concurrency certification. Trips generated by projects below the threshold level shall be recorded and applied to the traffic circulation network as part of the annual certification process. 
g.  Proposed development which generates 500 or more average daily trips shall submit a traffic impact analysis at the time an application for development approval is filed. This traffic analysis shall, at a minimum, include an analysis generated by the VCOG traffic analysis system. 
h.  Evaluation of the impact of proposed development upon roadway levels-of-service must take into consideration both the relative impact from adjoining jurisdictions and the relative responsibility of various jurisdictions to provide for improvements. This is particularly true for the following State Roads: Nova Road, Beville Road and Ridgewood Avenue (U.S. Highway 1), over which the FDOT has primary jurisdiction and responsibility for financing needed improvements. To the extent that planned improvements are behind schedule on these roadways due to no fault of the city (Nova Road is a notable case in point), the city should not be unduly and unfairly restricted from approving a limited amount of development so long as it does not substantially degrade the existing level- of-service. Additional traffic permitted on backlogged facilities will be governed by the level of services limits set by Policy 1-8 of the adopted Traffic Circulation Element of the South Daytona Comprehensive Plan. 
i.  Levels-of-service on local roadways within the city shall not be allowed to deteriorate to a level-of- service below the adopted "C" level-of-service standard for all local roadways. 
j.  In August/September of each year the city will discuss and coordinate roadway level-of-service issues with those entities either having primary responsibility for the roadways or directly affected by them: i.e. Volusia County, FDOT, local MPO, Daytona Beach, Port Orange and Daytona Beach Shores. 
k.  In September of each year, after coordinating with affected entities, the city will issue a roadway capacity reservation certification to cover both the following fiscal year and every succeeding year of the five-year period which begins with that initial fiscal year. This certification will indicate the specific capacity levels which will be allowed for each roadway within the city limits plus Beville Road. 
2.  Potable water facilities. In September of each year the city will obtain a potable water capacity reservation certification from the City of Daytona Beach. This certification will cover at least the following fiscal year and the five-year period which starts with that fiscal year. It will be based upon the projected city population for the periods in question multiplied by the projected city demand in gallons per capita (i.e. the city's adopted level-of-service standard for potable water facilities). The impact of a specific project will be calculated by determining the year of impact and then multiplying the population of the project at that point in time by the projected demand per capita (i.e. the city's adopted level-of-service standard for potable water facilities); then that final demand at impact for the project will be added to the final demand for any other proposed projects, and the cumulative total will be compared to the potable water capacity reservation certification to determine capacity availability for the specific project. 
In addition, all projects must be reviewed as to the adequacy of water pressure and water storage capacity according to the city's adopted level-of-service standards for those parameters. 
3.  Sanitary sewer facilities. In September of each year, the city will obtain a sanitary sewer capacity reservation certification from the City of Daytona Beach. This certification will cover at least the following fiscal year and the five-year period which starts with that fiscal year. It will be based upon the projected city population for the periods in question multiplied by the projected city flow in gallons per capita (i.e. the city's adopted level-of-service standard for sanitary sewer facilities). 
The impact of a specific project will be calculated by determining the year of impact and then multiplying the population of the project at that point in time by the projected flow per capita (i.e. the city's adopted level-of- service standard for sanitary sewer facilities); then that final demand at impact for the project will be added to the final demand for any other proposed projects, and the cumulative total will be compared to the sanitary sewer capacity reservation certification to determine capacity availability for the specific project. 
4.  Solid waste facilities. In September of each year the city will obtain a solid waste capacity reservation certification from Volusia County. This certification will cover at least both the following fiscal year and the five-year period which starts with that fiscal year. It will be based upon the projected city population for the periods in question multiplied by the projected city disposal in pounds per capita (i.e. the city's adopted level-of-service standard for solid waste facilities). 
The impact of a specific project will be calculated by determining the year of impact and then multiplying the population of the project at that a point in time by the projected disposal per capita (i.e. the city's adopted level-of-service standard for solid waste facilities), then that final demand at impact for the project will be added to the final demand for any other proposed projects, and the cumulative total will be compared to the solid waste capacity reservation certification to determine capacity availability for the specific project. 
5.  Drainage facilities. In September of each year the city will issue its own one- and five-year drainage facility adequacy certification which will state that concurrency compliance is assumed based upon the city's enforcement of its adopted level-of-service standard for on-site drainage. 
6.  Park and recreation facilities. In September of each year the city will issue its own recreation capacity reservation certification. This certification will cover at least both the following fiscal year and the five-year period (on a year-by-year basis) which starts with that fiscal year. It will be based upon the projected city population (in 1,000's) for the periods in question multiplied by the city's adopted level-of-service standard(s) (units per 1,000) for recreation facilities. 
The impact of a specific project will be calculated by determining the year of impact and then multiplying the population of the project (in 1,000's) at that point in time by the city's adopted level-of-service standard(s) (units per 1,000) for recreation facilities; then that final demand at impact for the project will be added to the final demand for any other projects proposed for the same fiscal year, and the cumulative total will be compared to the recreation capacity reservation certification for the time period in question to determine capacity availability for the specific project. 
E.  Projected need for additional facilities to meet concurrency requirement. 
1.  In the event that the city's concurrency analysis reveals that proposed or projected development will result in a concurrency deficiency in any one or more of the six types of critical public facilities for a particular fiscal year of project impact, the city must make sure that there is a financial or other legally binding commitment to correct the deficiency before it makes a finding of concurrency compliance on specific affected projects. This will require either the inclusion of timely remedial funding in the city's annual capital improvement program's budget, developer commitment (legally binding) to provide remedial funding, or some other legally binding obligation to correct the deficiency in a timely manner. 
2.  In the event that a development order or permit should not otherwise be issued due to the unavailability of adequate funding for necessary public facilities, the city will allow the developer to provide the facilities at his own expense contingent upon: the public facilities to be provided must not be inconsistent with the schedule of capital improvements in the comprehensive plan; the city and the developer must execute an enforceable development agreement which includes a construction schedule and a monitoring mechanism and penalty clauses (in case of non-compliance) to ensure concurrency. However, mere availability of public facility capacity for a proposed project, even if such availability is provided totally through developer financing, is not in itself sufficient justification for project approval; all of the city's project review criteria must be satisfied before the project can be approved. 
3.  In the event that available facility capacity will be insufficient to serve all competing development applications impacting in a given fiscal year and being reviewed simultaneously, the city will complete its review process and then prioritize the approval applications, and it will approve them in rank order only to the extent that it is determined that concurrent capacity will be available. Approvable applications will be ranked on a "first come, first served" basis by date of application in chronological order. 
4.  In the event that a project is rejected either because capacity is unavailable for it or through the ranking procedure described in the preceding paragraph, the city reserves the right to exercise the following options: deny the project; or defer the project; or require project modification; or conditionally approve the project. If the project is denied or deferred, the applicant will be given the opportunity to leave his application on file or to resubmit it when facility capacity becomes available. Such applications will be given chronological priority over subsequent applications but must be reviewed for full concurrency compliance if more than 45 days elapse between denial/deferral and reconsideration. 
F.  Vested rights. "Vested" means that a property is not subject to concurrency requirements because it was approved on or before April 10, 1990, the date of adoption of the city's comprehensive plan. Existing vacant residential, commercial, industrial and public buildings are considered vested. Vacant single-family building lots in platted and recorded subdivisions are considered vested. This means that any homes built upon those lots are also vested. Other projects must have had an active building permit as of April 10, 1990 to be considered vested. 
G.  "Last resort" provision. As a "last resort" measure, the city reserves the right to deny, delay or conditionally approve any development application or permit which would otherwise be issuable if the project review process clearly demonstrates, based upon convincing reasoning and documentation, that approval would adversely impact the levels-of- service of critical public facilities in such a way as to pose a clear threat to the health, safety or welfare of the community. 
H.  Capacity reservation fee. The city council may establish a capacity reservation fee in recognition of the value inherent in the reservation of service capacity for a specific development for a stated period of time. The award of the capacity reservation prevents the city from awarding this same capacity to another project. The specific fee will be established by resolution. 
I.  No later than August or September of each fiscal year, the concurrency manager will provide a report to the city council which evaluates the past performance of the CMS and, if needed, makes recommendations for improvement. This report may be combined with any other related report which must be issued during the same period. 
J.  Administration. Although the city council has the ultimate responsibility for the implementation of the CMS, various city agencies and officials carry out functions in the program. The city manager, as concurrency manager, provides administrative oversight for the program. However, the community development director/chief building official will be responsible for the day-to-day concurrency management decisions such as concurrency evaluations and the issuance of concurrency compliance certifications and building permits. Such agencies as the land development regulation board (LDRB) with respect to the comprehensive plan, subdivision review and concurrency appeals, and the board of adjustment with respect to other appeals, will exercise their statutory functions in the administrative process. 
K.  Appeals. 
1.  Except as otherwise provided in the City Code, appeals from concurrency determinations of city officials or agencies shall be taken before the land development regulation board (LDRB). Any such appeal must be filed in writing with the community development director (CDD) within 20 calendar days of rendition of the decision in question, and the reasons for such appeal shall be set forth therein. The CDD shall arrange for an appeal hearing before the LDRB and shall notify the appellant in writing of the date, time and place of the hearing. 
2.  The appellant shall have the burden of affirmatively demonstrating that the decision of the city official(s) was in error. Said official(s) shall have the opportunity to present information and argument to support the city's decision. 
3.  The board shall base its decision on the city's comprehensive plan and concurrency management regulations, and it shall make its decision employing its usual voting procedures. The decision shall be issued in writing stating the reasoning involved, and it shall be rendered within 60 days of the close of the hearing. 
4.  In the event that either the appellant or the concurrency manager wishes to appeal the matter further, that may be done to the city council by filing a written appeal, setting forth the reasons therefore, with the city clerk within 20 calendar days after rendition of the decision by the board. The city clerk shall arrange for a hearing before the city council, and shall notify the appellant in writing of the date, time and place of the hearing. Consideration shall be limited to the record established before the board and argument of the parties involved. The city council shall base its decision on applicable laws and regulations. It shall make its decision using its usual voting procedures. The decision shall be issued in writing stating the reasoning involved, and it shall be rendered within 60 days of the close of the hearing. No further administrative appeal is available beyond this stage, though the appellant retains the right of appeal through the judicial system.

Any additions or deletions made to said Matrix to reflect changes in regulatory management shall not require an amendment herein.

Sec. 4.4. - Proportionate fair-share transportation regulations. 
I.  Short title, authority, and applicability. 
(A)  This section shall be known as the "proportionate fair-share transportation regulations." 
(B)  The city council is required to adopt this section in accordance with the provisions of F.S. § 163.3180 (16). 
(C)  The provisions of this section shall apply to all developments within the City of South Daytona that impact a major roadway segment which has failed to achieve transportation concurrency by having a level-of-service below that adopted by the entity (whether city, county, or state) having competent jurisdiction. 
(D)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to developments of regional impact (DRI's) or to developments exempted from concurrency or to developments creating de minimis impacts. 
II.  Purpose and intent. The purpose and intent of this section is to establish a method for mitigating the impacts of development on transportation facilities through the cooperative efforts of the public and private sectors. More specifically, the proportionate fair-share mechanism is intended to enable developers to meet transportation concurrency requirements by paying their proportionate fair share of the cost of roadway improvements impacted by their proposed developments. 
III.  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall be defined as follows unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
(A)  Capital improvements. The outlay of capital of funds for the planning of, engineering of, acquisition of materials for, acquisition of land for, and construction of roads, related pedestrian/bikeways, turn lanes, intersection improvements and signalization; this does not include maintenance. 
(B)  Capital improvements plan. The five-year capital improvements schedule contained in the Comprehensive Plan of the City of South Daytona. 
(C)  Developer. Any person(s) or entity, whether public or private, undertaking the development of land. 
(D)  Fair-share transportation facilities fee. The fee required to be paid by a developer in accordance with the terms of this section ("proportionate fair-share transportation regulations"). 
(E)  Land. The earth, water, and air above, below, or on the surface, which term includes any improvements or structures customarily regarded as land. 
(F)  Land development activity generating traffic. The conduct of any building activity or the making of any material change in the use of any land or structure that attracts or produces vehicular trips over and above those produced by the existing state of the land, consequently placing an additional demand on the major roadway network. 
(G)  Major roadway network. All arterial and collector roadways within the city, including any such proposed roads necessitated by new development activity generating vehicular traffic. 
IV.  General requirements. 
(A)  A developer may choose to satisfy the transportation concurrency requirements of the city by making a proportionate fair-share contribution, pursuant to the following requirements: 
1.  The proposed development is consistent with the Comprehensive Plan and applicable Land Development Regulations; and 
2.  The five-year capital improvements schedule in the capital improvements element of the Comprehensive Plan includes a transportation capital improvement that, upon completion, will accommodate the additional traffic generated by the proposed development. 
(B)  The city may choose to allow a developer to satisfy transportation concurrency requirements by making a proportionate fair-share contribution to an improvement, that upon completion, will accommodate the additional traffic generated by the proposed development, which improvement is not contained in the five-year capital improvements schedule and one of the following conditions applies: 
1.  The city adds the improvement to the five-year capital improvements schedule no later than the next regular capital improvements schedule update of the Comprehensive Plan, provided that the improvement is financially feasible as defined by F.S. § 163.3180 (16)(b)(1); or 
2.  If the funds in the five-year capital improvements schedule are insufficient to fully fund the construction of the improvement, the city may enter into a proportionate fair-share agreement with the developer authorizing construction of that amount of development upon which the proportionate fair-share amount is calculated, if the proportionate fair-share amount in such agreement is sufficient to pay for one or more improvements which will, in the opinion of the city council, significantly benefit the impacted transportation system, provided that said improvements are adopted into the five-year capital improvements schedule no later than the next regular capital improvements update of the Comprehensive Plan. 
(C)  Any transportation capital improvement proposed to meet the developer's proportionate fair-share obligation must meet the design standards of the city for city-maintained roads and the design standards of other applicable governmental entities for roads under their jurisdiction. 
V.  Application process. 
(A)  A developer who applies to commence any land development activity which would result in a failure of a road segment to meet transportation concurrency may apply to the city for a proportionate fair-share agreement. 
(B)  Prior to submission of an application for a proportionate fair-share agreement, a pre-application meeting shall be held with city staff to discuss eligibility, application submittal requirements, potential mitigation options, and other relevant issues. If the road segment that would fail to meet transportation concurrency is on the Strategic Intermodal System (SIS), the Florida Dept. of Transportation (FDOT) shall be requested to participate in the pre-application meeting; other directly affected jurisdictions may also be invited to participate in said meeting. 
(C)  Application review procedures: 
1.  The developer shall submit an application to the community development director that includes a non-refundable application fee of $2,000.00 (which fee shall be credited toward what is ultimately determined to be the developer's proportionate fair-share contribution), plus the following: 
a.  Name, address and contact information of the developer; 
b.  A survey and legal description of the land; 
c.  Project schedule (including phases, if applicable); 
d.  Description of the requested fair-share mitigation; 
e.  If the requested fair-share mitigation involves a road segment on the Strategic Intermodal System (SIS), evidence of concurrence from FDOT; and 
f.  Traffic study performed by a licensed traffic engineer demonstrating failure of road segment to meet transportation concurrency. 
2.  Within 20 days of receipt of the application, the community development director shall conduct his review of the application to determine its completeness. If the application is not complete, a written statement shall be sent to the developer delineating the deficiencies; if such deficiencies are not remedied by the developer within 30 days of receipt of the written notice, then the application shall be deemed to be abandoned. The community development director, in his sole discretion, may grant an extension to cure such deficiencies if the developer shows good cause and has taken reasonable steps to effect a cure. 
3.  If the community development director determines that the application is complete, he shall provide written notification of such to the developer and forward the application to the city attorney, who shall, within 30 days, draft a proportionate fair-share agreement for consideration by the city council at a meeting to be held no later than 60 days from the date that the developer received notice that the application was complete. 
4.  No proportionate fair-share agreement shall be effective until approved by the city council. 
VI.  Determination of proportionate fair-share obligation. 
(A)  Proportionate fair-share mitigation may include, without limitation, separately or collectively, private funds, contributions of land, and contributions of transportation facilities. 
(B)  The methodology used to calculate a developer's proportionate fair-share obligation is represented by the following formula, pursuant to F.S. § 163.3180(12): 
Proportionate Share = [(Development Trips)/(SV Increase) × Cost] 
Where: 
Development Trips = Those trips from the development that are assigned to the affected roadway segment. 
SV Increase = Service volume increase provided by the improvement to the affected roadway segment. 
Cost = Adjusted cost of the improvement. 
(C)  For the purpose of determining proportionate fair-share obligations, improvement costs shall be based upon the actual cost of the improvement as obtained, as appropriate, from the city's five-year capital improvements schedule, the Transportation Improvement Program of the Volusia County MPO, the Road Program of the County of Volusia, or the Work Program of FDOT. If information is not available from such sources, the improvement cost shall be determined using one of the following methods: 
1.  An analysis by the community development department of costs, adjusted by the FDOT Price Trends Index from the previous year, by cross section type, that incorporates data from recent projects; or 
2.  The most recent issue of the FDOT "Transportation Costs," as adjusted based upon the type of cross section; locally available data from recent projects as to acquisition, drainage, and utility costs; and significant changes in the cost of materials due to unforeseeable events. 
(D)  If the city has accepted an improvement project proposed by the developer, the value of the improvement shall be determined using one of the methods provided in this section. 
(E)  If the city has accepted right-of-way dedication for the proportionate fair-share payment, credit for the dedication of the non-site related right-of-way shall be valued as of the date of the dedication at 120 percent of the most recent assessed value by the Volusia County Property Appraiser or, with mutual agreement of the city and the developer, by fair market value established by an independent appraisal approved by the city and not at city expense. The developer shall supply to the city a certificate of title or title search of the land at no expense to the city. If the estimated value of the right-of-way dedication proposed by the developer is less than the city-estimated total proportionate fair-share obligation for the development, then the developer must pay the difference. 
VII.  Transportation facilities impact fee credit. 
(A)  Proportionate fair-share mitigation payments shall be applied as a credit against impact fees. Credits will be given for that portion of the impact fees that would have been used to fund the improvements upon which the proportionate fair-share contribution is calculated. Also, if the proportionate fair-share contribution is based upon only a portion of the traffic generated by the development, the credit will be limited to that portion of the impact fees upon which the proportionate fair-share contribution is based. 
(B)  At the time that the proportionate fair-share obligation is being determined, the city will also compute the transportation facilities impact fee obligation for the proposed development. If the developer's proportionate fair-share obligation is less than the total transportation facilities impact fee anticipated for the development, the developer must pay the difference to the city. 
VIII.  Proportionate fair-share agreements. 
(A)  If the developer fails to apply for a building permit within one year of the date of execution of the proportionate fair-share agreement, the agreement shall be considered null and void, and the developer shall be required to reapply in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(B)  Payment of the proportionate fair-share contribution is due in full prior to issuance of the final development order or recording of the final plat and shall be nonrefundable. If the payment is submitted after one year from the date of execution of the agreement, the proportionate fair-share cost shall be recalculated at the time of payment based upon the best estimate of construction cost of the required improvement at the time of payment pursuant to these regulations and adjusted accordingly. 
(C)  Developer improvements authorized herein involving dedications to the city must be completed upon final acceptance of the improvements and receipt of a warranty bond in a form approved by the city attorney. 
(D)  Developer improvements authorized herein not involving dedications to the city must be completed upon recording of a final plat or upon issuance of a certificate of occupancy, whichever occurs first. 
(E)  Any requested change to a development project subsequent to the issuance of a development order will be subject to additional proportionate fair-share contributions to the extent that the change would generate additional traffic. 
(F)  A developer may present the city with a letter to withdraw from the proportionate fair-share agreement at any time prior to the execution of the agreement. However, the application fee paid to the city shall be nonrefundable. 
IX.  Appropriation of fair-share revenues. 
(A)  All proportionate fair-share revenues shall be placed in the appropriate project account for funding of improvements contained in the five-year capital improvements schedule, or for use as might otherwise be established as per terms of the proportionate fair-share agreement. 
(B)  In the event that a scheduled transportation facility improvement is removed from the five-year capital improvements schedule, then the revenues already collected for its construction shall be applied toward the construction of another improvement within the same transportation corridor that would mitigate the impacts of development, as determined by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 06-21, § 1, 12-12-06) 
ARTICLE V. - ZONING REGULATIONS 

Sec. 5.1. - General provisions. 
A.  Title. These regulations shall be known as the "Zoning Regulations (or Zoning Code) of the City of South Daytona, Florida." 
B.  Purpose and intent. These zoning regulations have been prepared with due consideration to existing conditions and future development of the city according to general policies expressed in the Comprehensive Land Use Plan as adopted by the city council on April 10, 1990 and any subsequent amendments. 
    This article is designed to promote the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the city by regulating the use and development of land and water: 
1.  To provide for an efficient, equitable, economical, and environmentally sound pattern of urban development; 
2.  To secure safety from fire, wind, and other dangers; 
3.  To provide adequate light and air and to prevent the overcrowding of land; 
4.  To avoid undue concentration of population; and 
5.  To facilitate provision for adequate transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks, and other public needs; and 
6.  To place similar land uses together in the same district and to minimize incompatibilities between different adjoining land uses. 
    The zoning regulations and districts are developed in light of the aforementioned objectives and considering the character of the districts and their suitability for particular uses of land. These regulations and districts work toward preserving desirable environmental features while allowing the greatest possible use and enjoyment of individual properties. They strive to protect the values of buildings and land and the use and enjoyment of adjacent properties. In general, the zoning regulations regulate land use and land development with the overarching goal of promoting and protecting the public welfare. 
C.  Jurisdiction. The provisions of this article shall apply inside the corporate limits of the City of South Daytona, Florida. 
Sec. 5.2. - Establishment of districts and official zoning map. 
A.  Establishment of districts. The City of South Daytona, Florida, is hereby divided into zoning districts as specified in this article and shown on the official zoning map of the city which, together with all explanatory material therein, is hereby adopted by reference and declared to be a part of these zoning regulations. 
B.  Official zoning map. 
1.  Identification of official map: The official zoning map shall be identified by the signature of the mayor of the City of South Daytona, be attested by the city clerk, and bear the seal of the city under the following words: "This is to certify that this is the Official Zoning Map referred to in the Zoning Regulations of the City of South Daytona, Florida." 
2.  Changes in district boundaries: If, in accordance with provisions of this article, changes are made in district boundaries or other matter on the official zoning map, such changes shall be recorded promptly on the map by inserting the date when the amendment was adopted, the ordinance number adopting the amendment, and the mayor's signature attested by the city clerk, in the spaces provided for such entries. 
3.  Official map final authority: Regardless of the existence of so-called "versions" and copies of the city zoning map which may from time-to-time be made or published, the official zoning map, which shall be kept under the responsible charge of the city clerk, shall be the final graphic authority as to the current zoning status of land and water areas, buildings, and other structures within the city limits. However, the legal description of all zoning ordinances shall be the final legal authority as to the zoning status of land. 
4.  Retention of earlier zoning maps: All zoning maps or remaining portions thereof which have had official force and effect in the city prior to the effective date of these zoning regulations shall be retained as a public record and as a guide to the zoning status of lands and water under the jurisdiction of the city prior to the adoption of this Code. 
5.  Replacement of official zoning map: In the event that the official zoning map becomes damaged, destroyed, lost, or difficult to interpret because of the nature or number of changes and additions, or because of deterioration, the city council shall act to replace the prior official zoning map. The new official zoning map may correct drafting or other errors or omissions in the prior official zoning map, but no such correction shall have the effect of amending the original official zoning map or any subsequent amendment thereof. The new official zoning map shall be identified by the signature of the mayor of the City of South Daytona, attested by the city clerk, and bear the seal of the city under the following words: "This is to certify that this Official Zoning Map supersedes and replaces the Official Zoning Map adopted on the ____________ / ____________ / ____________ day of ____________ , by Ordinance No. ____________ of South Daytona, Florida." (Insert date map was replaced). Unless the prior Official Zoning Map has been lost or totally destroyed, the prior map or any significant parts thereof remaining shall be preserved together with all available records pertaining to its adoption or amendment. 
6.  Updating zoning base maps: No revision of zoning boundaries is permitted except by ordinance. However, from time-to-time the zoning base map may be updated to reflect new annexations and streets and subdivisions formally approved by the city council without further official action by that body. 
Sec. 5.3. - Rules for interpretation of district boundaries. 
A.  Interpretation of district boundaries. Where uncertainty exists as to the boundaries of districts as shown on the official zoning map, the following rules shall apply: 
1.  Boundaries approximately following streets, highways, alleys, or rights-of-way: Boundaries indicated as approximately following the centerlines of streets, highways, alleys, or rights-of-way shall be construed to follow such centerlines. In the event a right-of-way is vacated, the district boundary shall be construed as remaining in its location except when ownership of the vacated street is divided other than at the center, in which case the boundary shall be construed as moving with the ownership. 
2.  Boundaries approximately following platted lot lines: Boundaries indicated as approximately following platted lot lines shall be construed as following such lot lines. 
3.  Boundaries approximately following city limits: Boundaries indicated as approximately following city limits shall be construed as following such city limits. 
4.  Boundaries approximately following railroad lines: Boundaries indicated as following railroad lines shall be construed to be midway between the main tracks. 
5.  Boundaries approximately following bulkhead lines, shore lines, streams, or other water bodies: Boundaries indicated as following bulkhead or shore lines shall be construed to follow such bulkhead lines or shore lines, and in the event of change, the bulkhead line or shore line shall be construed as moving with the newly established bulkhead line or the actual shore line; boundaries indicated as approximately following the centerlines of streams, rivers, canals, lakes, or other bodies of water shall be construed to follow such centerlines. 
6.  Boundaries indicated as entering any body of water: Boundaries that are indicated as entering any body of water, but not continuing to intersect with other zoning boundaries, shall be construed as extending in the direction in which they enter the body of water to intersect with other zoning districts. 
7.  Boundaries approximately parallel to or extensions of above features: Boundaries indicated as parallel to or extensions of features shall be so construed. Distances not specifically indicated on the official zoning map shall be determined by the scale of the map. 
8.  District boundary dividing a lot: Where a district boundary divides a lot of record at the time the boundary was established and where the division makes impractical the reasonable use of the lot, the extension of the regulations for either portion of the lot may be permitted, not to exceed 50 feet beyond the district line into the remaining portion of the lot. 
B.  Community development director (CDD) to interpret boundaries in cases of discrepancy between actual features and zoning map: Where discrepancies exist between natural or manmade features existing on the ground and those not shown on the official zoning map, or in other circumstances not covered by sections above, the CDD shall interpret the district boundaries. 
Sec. 5.4. - Application of district regulations. 
A.  Zoning affects all land, buildings and structures. No building, structure, or land shall hereafter be used or occupied, and no building or structure or part thereof shall hereafter be erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved, or structurally altered except in conformity with the regulations herein specified for the district in which it is located, or as otherwise provided for in this article or the nonconforming provisions of the City Code. 
B.  Buildings shall conform to code requirements. No building or other structure shall hereafter be erected or altered, except for repair work on nonconforming structures: 
1.  To exceed the height, bulk, or floor area, 
2.  To provide a greater number of dwelling units, 
3.  To occupy a greater percentage of lot area, 
4.  To have narrower or smaller rear yards, front yards or side yards, 
5.  To provide less lot area per dwelling unit or to occupy a smaller lot, or 
6.  Provide a lesser separation between buildings or portion of buildings, than therein required or in any manner contrary to the provisions of this Code. 
C.  Multiple use of required space prohibited. No part of a yard or other open space or off-street parking or loading space required about or in connection with any building for the purpose of complying with this Code shall be included as part of a yard, open space, or off-street parking or loading space similarly required for any other building, except as specifically provided for in this Code. 
D.  Reduction of lot area prohibited. No yard or lot existing at the time of passage of this Code shall be reduced in dimension or area below the minimum requirements set forth herein for the district in which it is located. Yards or lots created after the effective date of this Code shall meet the minimum requirements established by this Code. 
E.  Uses not permitted by right. Uses not designated as permitted by right, allowed by special exception or as a special use, or accessory to these uses, shall be prohibited from that district except for special event permit uses elsewhere provided for in this Code. If a question arises as to the interpretation of any permitted uses, such interpretation shall be made by the city manager and/or administrative official or, at his request, by the city council directly. 
F.  Effect on previously approved and existing developments. Any site plan or subdivision approved by the city prior to the effective date of this Code may be developed under the dimensional requirements in effect at the time of approval. However, if construction of such a development does not commence within the time period specified by the city, the administrative official shall review the final site plans, and may require conformance with any or all current development standards. 
Sec. 5.5. - Schedule of zoning district regulations. 
A.  Establishment of zoning districts. This ordinance establishes the following zoning districts which regulate land uses and development in the city:

C.  R-1A single-family residential district.

Single-family dwellings; 
Public parks. 
3.  Accessory uses: Uses customarily associated with, dependent on, and incidental to, the principal use. 
4.  Special exceptions: None

1.  Purpose and intent: This district is intended to protect existing residential development of similar nature and to provide for future residential development. 
2.  Permitted uses: 
Single-family dwellings; 
Public parks. 
3.  Accessory uses: Uses customarily associated with, dependent on, and incidental to, the principal use. 
4.  Special exceptions: None. 
5.  Dimensional requirements - see Figure 2. 
E.  R-1C single-family residential district. 
1.  Purpose and intent: This district is intended to protect existing residential development of similar nature and to provide for new infill development. 
2.  Permitted uses: 
Single-family dwellings; 
public parks. 
3.  Accessory uses: Uses customarily associated with, dependent on, and incidental to, the principal use. 
4.  Special exceptions: None. 
5.  Dimensional requirements - see Figure 2. 
F.  R-2 single-family, two-family residential district. 
1.  Purpose and intent: This district is intended to provide for areas where more affordable housing is desired. It may serve as a transitional zone between multiple-family and single-family housing areas. 
2.  Permitted uses: 
Single-family dwellings; 
Two-family dwellings; 
Public parks. 
3.  Accessory uses: Uses customarily associated with, dependent on, and incidental to, the principal use. 
4.  Special exceptions: None. 
5.  Dimensional requirements - see Figure 2. 
G.  R-3 Multiple-family residential district. 
1.  Purpose and intent: The intent of the R-3 district is to provide for the construction of multiple-family dwellings on tracts of single or common ownership; require the preparation and approval of detailed site plans; and require a sufficient amount of open space. Properties in the R-3 district shall have direct access to an arterial, collector or minor collector as designated by the comprehensive plan. 
2.  Permitted uses: 
Condominiums; 
Townhouses; 
Apartments; 
Multiple-family dwellings; 
Single-family dwellings on lots of one acre or less provided that the setbacks and other dimensional requirements for the "R-1a" Zoning Classification are applied; 
Duplex dwellings on lots of one acre or less provided that the setbacks and other dimensional requirements for the "R-2 2F" Zoning Classification are applied. 
Public parks; 
Existing single-family dwelling on a lot of record; 
Recreational uses. 
3.  Accessory uses: Uses customarily associated with, dependent on and incidental to, the primary uses. These include uses such as recreation facilities, laundry rooms, maintenance buildings and community buildings. 
4.  Special exceptions: None. 
5.  Dimensional requirements: The following dimensional requirements shall apply to multi-family development in all R-3 areas: 
a.  Minimum project size: The minimum project size shall be one acre. However, on existing lots of record designated by the comprehensive plan as suitable for multiple-family development, projects on smaller sites may be approved. 
b.  Project density: The maximum number of dwelling units shall not exceed ten units per gross acre. 
c.  Project perimeter setbacks: Front, rear and side setbacks shall be designed so that no building is located closer than 25 feet from a public right-of-way. Setbacks from interior property lines shall be equal to or greater than the height of the tallest building in the development, but in no case shall be less than 20 feet. 
d.  Building spacing requirements: Fifty feet between any combination of fronts or rears of adjacent buildings. Twenty-five feet between any other combination of principal buildings. 
e.  Maximum building height: The maximum building height shall be 35 feet. 
f.  Location of parking areas: No parking or drives shall be located in the first 20 feet of the required front yard except for direct access drives through the yard. Driveways or parking areas may be permitted in the side or rear yards but may not be within ten feet of a property line or any building. 
g.  Sidewalks: Sidewalks shall be constructed along all public streets. 
6.  Open space and landscaping: At least 40 percent of the project site shall be retained as open space. Open space does not include any land area devoted to buildings, sidewalks, interior streets, parking areas or access drives. All open space areas shall be landscaped in accordance with the city's landscape ordinance. 
7.  Development plan review: Prior to the issuance of a building permit, a site plan approval shall be obtained according to the provisions of Article III of this Code. 
H.  MHP - mobile home park residential district. 
1.  Purpose and intent: This district is intended to provide for adequate areas for mobile home development owned and managed as a single unit. These areas are reserved exclusively for mobile homes because the mixing of mobile homes and conventional dwellings is found to create incompatibilities among both dwelling types. 
2.  Permitted uses: 
Mobile home parks; 
Public parks. 
3.  Accessory uses: Uses customarily associated with, dependent on and incidental to, the principal use. These uses include such items as recreation facilities, laundry rooms, community buildings and park management offices. 
4.  Special exceptions: None. 
5.  Dimensional requirements: 
a.  Minimum project size: The minimum project size shall be five acres. 
b.  Maximum density: The maximum density shall not exceed nine units per gross acre. 
c.  Minimum yard requirements: Each mobile home park shall have a front yard of 40 feet. All other park lot lines shall have a yard of 15 feet. 
6.  Mobile home park development standards. 
a.  Mobile home space: Each mobile home space shall be a minimum of 4,000 square feet and shall be at least 40 feet in width. The minimum yards required between mobile homes, including accessory structures, shall be eight feet for the front yard and five feet for side and rear yards. 
b.  Access roads: Access roads within a mobile home park shall be paved to a width of not less than 20 feet in a common access area of at least 40 feet. All access roads will be paved in accordance with city specifications. Sidewalks not less than four feet in width shall be provided along all access roads. All access roads and walkways shall be lighted with an average illumination of at least 0.3 foot candles. 
c.  Parking: The required parking for each unit shall be located on the same lot as that unit. Where common facilities are provided, additional parking shall be required in accordance with this Code. 
d.  Utilities: All dwellings and public buildings shall be served by municipal water and sewer systems. 
7.  Development plan review: Prior to the issuance of a building permit, a development plan approval shall have been issued according to the provisions of this Code. 
I.  MHS - mobile home subdivision residential district. 
1.  Purpose and intent: This district is intended to provide for adequate areas for mobile home development on subdivided lots. These areas are reserved exclusively for mobile homes because the mixing of mobile homes and conventional dwellings is found to create incompatibilities among both dwelling types. 
2.  Permitted uses: 
Mobile home subdivisions; 
Public parks. 
3.  Accessory uses: Uses customarily associated with, dependent on and incidental to, the principal use. These uses include such items as recreation facilities, laundry rooms, and community rooms. 
4.  Special exceptions: 
None. 
5.  Dimensional requirements: 
a.  Minimum project size: The minimum project size shall be five acres. 
b.  Maximum density: The maximum density shall be exceed nine units per gross acre. 
c.  Minimum yard requirements: Each mobile home subdivision shall have a front yard setback of 40 feet with side and rear yard setbacks of 15 feet. 
6.  Mobile home subdivision development standards: 
a.  Subdivision requirements: All mobile home subdivisions shall meet the requirements of the subdivision ordinance. 
b.  Parking: The required parking for each unit shall be located on the same lot as that unit. Where common facilities are provided, additional parking shall be required in accordance with this Code. 
c.  Open space: A minimum of 400 square feet of common open space per unit shall be provided. Required setbacks, easements and street rights-of-way shall not be considered part of the common open space. 
d.  Homeowner's association: Each subdivision shall establish a homeowners' association or similar entity approved by the city attorney to maintain all common areas and required setbacks.

Automotive related uses and certain other types of businesses are permitted as special exceptions. It is intended that automotive uses be located on arterial roads in clusters at intersections with these arterial roads.

M.  BHC - business heavy commercial district. 
1.  Purpose and intent: The purpose and intent of the business heavy commercial district is to provide for those storage and commercial uses which are too intensive for general commercial areas or are disruptive of general commercial development patterns. These uses would include mini-warehouses, retail sales, activities which typically require outdoor storage, and automotive repair. 
Proper buffering is required in relation to other uses, and these districts should generally be located on arterial roadways. 
2.  Permitted uses: Uses permitted in the business heavy commercial district are limited to those specifically stated below:

4.  Special exceptions:

5.  Development plan review: Prior to the issuance of a building permit, a development plan shall be required under the provisions of this Code. 
6.  Dimensional requirements - see Figure 2. 
N.  LI - light industrial district. 
1.  Purpose and intent: The primary purpose and intent of this district is to adequately locate and regulate limited industrial operations engaged in the fabricating, repair, or storage of manufactured goods from which no objectionable by-products of the activity (such as odors, smoke, dust, refuse, electromagnetic interference, or excessive noise) are noticeable beyond the lot on which the facility is located. Other uses which are not readily compatible with other zoning districts may be considered for location in the LI district. 
2.  Permitted uses: Manufacturing or distribution of the following products or location of the following businesses is permitted in the LI district:
