Certain palms such as Canary Island, Pindo, and Majool may, due to their elegance and high value, be substituted for specified shade trees on a tree-for-tree basis. 
However, the use of Eucalyptus (camaldulensis), Australian pine (Casuarina equisetifolia), punk (melaleuca leucadendra) and Brazilian Pepper (schinus terebinthifolius) shall be prohibited under this section. 
b.  Shrubs and hedges. Shrubs, including hedges, shall be a minimum of two and one-half feet in height at the time of planting, and they must be a minimum three-gallon size. Shrubs must be planted at a distance not to exceed three feet on center. Hedges, where required, shall be planted and maintained so as to form a continuous unbroken, solid, visual screen within a maximum of one year after time of planting. Hedge plants are to be planted at distances no greater than 30 inches on center. 
c.  Ground cover. Ground cover of plant materials that reach an average height of not more than 18 inches may be used in lieu of grass, in whole or in part. These plants shall be a minimum one-gallon size, with a spacing that varies according to species but is never more than 36 inches on center. They shall be planted in such a manner so as to present a finished appearance with reasonably complete coverage. 
d.  Lawn grass. Grass areas shall be planted and may be sodded, plugged, sprigged, or seeded with native species. Solid sod shall be used in swales or other areas subject to erosion and providing that in areas where other than solid sod or grass seed is used, nurse grass seed shall be sown for immediate effect and protection until coverage is achieved. When sodding is used in any landscape application in the city, it shall be placed so as to provide a continuous and smooth contour. 
E.  Installation and maintenance. All landscaping shall be installed in a sound workmanship-like manner and according to accepted good planting procedures. All trees and palms must be properly staked at time of installation. The landscaping shall be installed so as to meet all applicable ordinances and code requirements. 
    The owner shall be responsible for the maintenance of all landscaping which shall be maintained in good condition so as to present a healthy, neat and orderly appearance and shall be kept free from weeds, refuse, and debris. Any installation which was made prior to the adoption of this Code, and in conformance with an approved site plan, shall be maintained in conformance with this Code. 
    All landscaped areas shall be provided with an automatic underground irrigation system, equipped with a rain sensor, adequate to service the landscaped areas. In the event that trees, shrubs, or other landscaped materials die, such materials shall be replaced within 30 days. In case of a natural disaster which destroys over 50 percent of the trees on the affected properties, the property owner shall have six months to replace the trees as required by this Article. Failure of the owner of the property to maintain the premises in good condition, as set forth above, shall make the owner liable for the penalties as set forth in Article IX. 
    No landscaped area may be abandoned, paved, or otherwise employed, without applying for and obtaining an amendment to an approved site plan pursuant to this article. 
F.  Landscaping adjacent to public right-of-way. Wherever a vehicular use area will not be entirely screened visually from any abutting right-of-way, except a dedicated alley, there shall be provided landscaping between such VUA and right-of-way as follows: 
1.  A strip of land at least seven feet in depth located adjacent to the abutting right-of-way, shall be landscaped, per the requirements of a Type 1 bufferyard. 
The remainder of the required landscaped areas shall be landscaped with grass, ground cover, or other acceptable materials, excluding paving, sand or gravel. 
Lands located along streets identified by the city for special treatment shall be planted with street trees in accordance with the provisions found in the South Daytona Streetscape Plan. 
2.  All property, other than the required landscape strip, lying between the street and VUA shall be landscaped with a combination of shrubs, ground cover, and trees equal to at least 50 percent of the landscape materials requirement. 
3.  Necessary accessways from the public right-of-way through all such landscaping shall be permitted to service the vehicular use area, and such accessways may be subtracted from the lineal dimension used to determine the number of trees required. 
G.  Perimeter landscaping relating to abutting properties. 
1.  Wherever a VUA will not be entirely screened visually from abutting property by an intervening building or structure, the portion of such VUA not so screened shall be provided with a landscape barrier meeting the requirements of a Type 1 bufferyard or a more restrictive bufferyard if required by the site use. The applicant is encouraged to incorporate earthen mounding, curvilinear design and offset placement of requirement plant life. Any perimeter landscaping strip in excess of ten feet shall incorporate these design standards. 
2.  Landscaping shall be provided in accordance with Type 1 bufferyard requirements. 
H.  Interior landscaping requirements. An area or combination of areas, equal to a minimum of ten percent of the total square footage of the VUA, shall be devoted to landscaping and may be counted as part of the interior landscaping requirement. When the VUA is adjacent to a structure or structures on the same parcel of land, any landscaping on said parcel which serves to beautify the VUA may be counted toward meeting the interior landscaping requirements. 
    Such landscaped areas shall be located in such a manner as to divide and break up the monotony of paving, or to prevent and discourage erratic vehicular movement. A combination of the following interior landscaping elements shall be counted as part of the interior landscaping requirements where applicable. 
1.  Landscape islands. Rows of parking spaces shall be separated every ten spaces and terminated on both ends by landscaped islands which measure an average of not less than ten feet in side width and extend the entire lengthy of the parking space(s). At least one tree, or grouping, shall be planted on said island. Landscape islands must be bounded by a concrete curb, minimum six high. 
2.  All parking rows shall be separated with a minimum landscape area of four feet above and beyond any landscaped vehicular overhang area. 
3.  In VUA's where the strict application of this section will seriously limit the function of said area, the required landscaping may be located near the perimeter of the paved area, including any perimeter which may be adjacent to a building on the site. This required interior landscaping shall be in addition to the required perimeter landscaping. 
4.  Parking spaces shall be designed through the use of wheel stops, curbing, or raised sidewalks to prevent the encroachment of vehicles upon or into landscaped areas and encourage runoff to the landscaped area only. (Encroachment is defined as any protrusion of a vehicle outside of a parking space, display area or accessway into a landscaped area). 
5.  All landscaping within a 15-foot radius of a fire hydrant shall consist of grass or ground cover which does not exceed 12 inches in height. When a fire hydrant is located in a terminal island, special treatment should be given to the placement of required plant material. 
I.  Unobstructed visibility at intersections. When an accessway intersects a public right-of-way, or when the subject property abuts the intersection of two or more public rights-of-way, all landscaping within the triangle areas described below shall provide unobstructed cross visibility at a level between three feet and seven feet, with the following proviso: that trees or palms shall have limbs and foliage trimmed in such a manner that no limbs or foliage extend into the cross-visibility area. The triangle areas referred to above, are: 
1.  The triangle areas within the property on both sides of the accessway formed by the intersection of each side of the accessway and the public right-of-way line with two sides of each triangle being ten feet in length from the point of intersection and the third side being a line connecting the ends of the other two sides. 
2.  The area of property located at the corner formed by the intersection of two or more public rights-of-way with two sides of the triangular area being 30 feet in length along the abutting public right-of-way lines, or projections thereof, measured from their point of intersection, and the third side being a line connecting the ends of the other two lines, and including all surfaced portions of the public right-of-way adjacent thereto. 
J.  Existing plant material. If the owner(s) can demonstrate that healthy plant material exists on a site prior to its development for the purposes of off-street parking or other vehicular use areas, the application of the above landscape standards may be adjusted to allow credit for such plant material if such an adjustment is in keeping with the intent of this section. 
K.  Stormwater management. All VUA's shall provide for adequate management of stormwater in accordance with the requirements of this Code, and they must be shown on all development plans. Areas required for landscaping may be used for stormwater management as long as the landscaping purposes of this section are not impeded. 
L.  Xeriscape. The use of xeriscape principles shall be allowed, particularly as a means of water conservation. 
M.  South Daytona Streetscape Guidelines. In order to improve the City's appearance, environment, and community welfare, the City hereby adopts by reference the document entitled "Streetscape Guidelines" (April, 1989). Those guidelines set forth concepts for planting of street trees along major roadway segments and other areas of the city. All proposed development falling within those described areas, shall be reviewed in light of those guidelines, as a supplement to the other landscape requirements found herein. 
N.  City inspection prior to installation of landscaping. Proposed landscaping project sites shall be inspected by the city prior to installation of the landscaping. The landscape installer shall submit a timely request for such an inspection to the community development department prior to installation. 
O.  City acceptance of landscaping projects. The community development director or his designee shall be responsible for acceptance of landscaping projects after they are completed. Prior to acceptance, the following actions are required: 
1.  A qualified city employee or contracted party shall inspect the landscaping to ensure that it meets city standards. 
2.  An as-built drawing of the landscaping shall be submitted to the community development department containing notes to the effect that the plants meet the "Florida #1" standard and that the installation meets the "sound workmanship" requirement. 
(Ord. No. 02-10, § 1, 7-23-02) 
Sec. 8.2. - Sign regulations. 
A.  Statement of purpose. The purpose of this section is to create regulations for the design, construction and location of signs to protect the public safety and welfare; to preserve the unique planned character and the natural and scenic environment of the city; to provide ample opportunity for business advertisement while preventing excessive, dangerous and unsightly signs; to prevent clutter among sign displays which would distract vehicle operators or place excessive demands on public attention and have a detrimental effect on the character and appearance of the residential, commercial and industrial areas of the city; to provide for adequate maintenance and inspection; and to reasonably assist potential customers in locating and identifying services, facilities and products offered within the city. 
B.  Applicability. This section is intended to cover all requirements relative to the types, sizes, heights, verbal content, permissible locations, restrictions, permits and licenses, inspections, identification, materials of manufacture and/or construction, methods of erection, and maintenance for all signs placed, installed, repaired, altered, replaced and/or erected within the city limits which are exposed to the out-of-doors view of the public. 
C.  Definitions. 
1.  Sign: means any device or display, including that portion of the supporting structure for freestanding or roof signs which consists of braces, uprights, or poles projecting from the ground or buildings, etc. and which is primarily designed to provide sign support comprised of letters, numbers, symbols, pictures,illustrations, announcements, cut-outs, insignia, trade marks or demonstrations, including all trim and borders, designed to advertise, inform, identify, or attract the attention of persons not on the display premises. A sign shall be constructed to be a single display surface, device, or unit containing elements organized, related and composed to form a single sign unit. 
The term sign means every billboard, ground sign, pole sign, elevated sign, marquee sign, mansard sign, awning sign, canopy sign, projecting sign, wall sign, roof sign, illuminated sign, street clock, real estate sign, or any other sign, and includes any announcement, declaration, demonstration, display, illustration, or insignia used to advertise or promote any particular interest when the sign is placed out of doors where is can be viewed by the public. 
2.  Abandoned (or obsolete) sign: means a sign which, for 180 consecutive calendar days, no longer advertises a bona fide and active business conducted or product sold. 
3.  Animated sign: means a sign upon which a character, letter or figure or group or combination thereof show movement or motion to such an extent as to be readily detected. 
4.  Awning sign: means a sign affixed to or part of a temporary shelter supported entirely from the exterior wall of a building and composed of non-rigid materials except for the supporting framework. 
5.  Banner sign: means a sign possessing characters, letters, illustrations or ornamentations applied to cloth, paper or fabric of any kind either with or without frames. 
6.  Bench sign: means any sign attached to or painted upon any bench or other device located upon public property and utilized for the seating of persons. 
7.  Billboard: means an outdoor ground sign, elevated ground sign, roof sign or wall sign upon which advertising matter may be painted or upon which posters may be pasted or otherwise secured on the face thereof advertising goods, services, or other things not sold or available upon the premises upon which the sign is located. 
8.  Canopy sign: means any permanent sign attached to or constructed in or on a canopy. 
9.  Changeable copy sign: means a sign on which copy is changed manually in the field; i.e., reader boards with changeable letters or pictorial panels. 
10.  Changing sign: means a sign, such as an electronically controlled public service time, temperature, and date sign or message center, where different copy changes are shows in the same lamp bank. 
11.  Construction sign: means a sign placed on property where construction is in progress and because construction is in progress; it may include the names of persons and firms performing services or supplying labor or materials to the premises. 
12.  Copy area: means the same thing as the term "sign area" (see definition in this section). 
13.  Directional signage: means signs used solely for the purpose of controlling on-site traffic flow. All signage shall meet design standards-e.g. for size, height, color, type, face, material, and location-presently used by the Florida Department of Transportation as defined in the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices of the Federal Highway Administration. 
14.  Directory sign: means a sign giving the name and/or occupation of a building; or gives the use of the building, including office building directories, church directories, and apartment house directories. A directory sign shall be a wall or ground sign 
15.  Erect: means to attach, alter, build, construct, reconstruct, enlarge, or move, and shall include the painting of wall signs, but does not include copy changes on any sign. 
16.  Facing or surface: means the surface of the sign upon, against, or through which the message is displayed or illustrated on the sign. 
17.  Flashing sign: means a sign or any part thereof which contains an intermittent or flashing light source, or which includes the illusion of intermittent or flashing lights by means of animation or an externally mounted intermittent light source. Automatic changing signs such as public service time, temperature and date signs or electronically controlled message centers are not classed as flashing signs. 
18.  Freestanding sign: means a ground or pole sign as defined in this section. 
19.  Ground sign: means a free-standing outdoor advertising display sign which meets the following requirements--either rests upon the ground or is supported on the ground with an air space not exceeding two feet between the ground and the underside of the sign; has a maximum height of eight feet above the ground. The term "ground sign" does not include the term "pole sign." 
20.  Lighted sign: means any sign which has characters, letters, figures, designs or outline illuminated by electric lights or luminous tubes as a part of the sign proper. 
21.  Marquee sign: means a sign attached to or hung from a marquee; and marquee means a canopy or covered structure projecting from and supported by a building when such canopy or covered structure extends beyond the building line or property line. 
22.  Mural: means a picture painted directly upon or permanently affixed to an exterior wall, whether residential or non-residential; any such mural is deemed to be a sign. 
23.  Non-conforming signs: means signs which are in violation of any part of this Code upon the effective date of this amendment thereto. 
24.  Other advertising structure: means any marquee, canopy, awning, or street clock as further defined herein. 
25.  Parked vehicle used as advertising sign: means a vehicle parked in a specific location for more than 24 hours which is clearly visible from public right-of-way and which has attached thereto or located thereon any sign or advertising device in excess of six square feet of sign area for the apparent purpose of providing advertisement of products or directing people to a business or business activity. 
26.  Pennants: means pieces of cloth, paper or fabric of any kind attached to a rope, string or cable and designed to create motion when attached to a sign or structure. 
27.  Pole sign: means a free-standing outdoor advertising display sign which is supported above the ground by means of a pole or poles, or similar support, projecting from the ground and not attached to any building; such a sign must have an air space between the underside of the sign and the ground of at least eight feet. The term "pole sign" does not include the term "ground sign". 
28.  Portable electrical sign: means a temporary electrical outdoor advertising display sign used in addition to regular business signs to advertise special events. 
29.  Professional sign: means a sign designating the office of a doctor, dentist, lawyer, accountant or other practicing professional. 
30.  Prohibited signs: means signs which are not allowed by the provisions of this Code. 
31.  Projecting sign: means an outdoor advertising display sign which is affixed to any building, wall or structure and extends beyond the building wall, structure, building line or property line. 
32.  Real estate sign: means any structure, device, display, board, screen, surface or wall with characters, letters or illustrations placed thereto or thereon where the matter displayed is solely for the purpose of offering real estate for sale or lease. 
33.  Replacing: means rebuilding, enlarging, or changing the size, structure, lettering, or sign copy, other than repainting or repair to electrical or mechanical apparatus. 
34.  Roof sign: means any sign erected, constructed, or maintained upon, against, or directly above a roof or on top of or above the parapet of a building in accordance with the Standard Building Code. Includes a sign located on a roof with a slope of 45 degree or less. 
35.  Sandwich sign: means any double- or single-faced sign which is portable and may readily be moved from place to place. 
36.  Shingle sign: means a wall sign not over 216 square inches in area attached securely to a building to identify the nature of the business located within. 
37.  Shopping center: means a group of commercial establishments, primarily retail, which are planned, developed, owned, or managed as a unit. 
38.  Shopping center sign: means an exterior sign located in a shopping center. 
39.  Sign area: means the surface area in square feet within any geometric figure or combination of figures encompassing all parts of a sign, including the outer extremities of all letters, figures, characters, background, frame, trim, molding, and decorative features, but excluding structural supports, whether they be columns, pylons, or a building or part thereof, unless the sign is affixed directly on the exterior surface of such structure. 
A projecting or ground sign with sign surface on both sides shall be considered a single sign, and the total area of such a sign shall be the area computed on a single face. A projecting or ground sign that is in a vee shape shall be computed as a single face sign, provided that the separation between the faces does not exceed three feet. 
40.  Sign rider: means a small sign which is temporarily attached to the perimeter of a larger real estate sign. 
41.  Sign unit: means any display or display device containing elements organized, related or composed to convey an integrated message. Where the display of any elements is in a random manner without any organized relationship of elements, each element shall be considered a separate sign. 
42.  Snipe sign: means a sign of any material, including paper, cardboard, wood and metal, when tacked, nailed or attached in any way to trees, telephone poles, power poles, street signs, or other objects where such sign may or may not apply to the premises, this definition includes cardboard signs on sticks. 
43.  Spectacular sign: means an outdoor advertising display sign with copy, usually animated, constructed of metal, wired for lights or luminous tubing, or both, with copy action control by the flasher circuit breakers or matographs and attached on an open face metal structure built especially for the purpose. 
44.  Subdivision sign: means a sign designed as apartment structure to identify a subdivision; such a sign shall not be used for development or promotional purposes, and shall only bear the name of the subdivision. 
45.  Temporary sign: means a sign which may be used only for a relatively short period of time and which typically consists of a banner, pennant, valance or advertising display constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric, paper, cardboard, wallboard or other light materials, with or without frames. 
46.  Under canopy sign: means a sign suspended below the ceiling of a canopy. 
47.  Wall sign: means an outdoor advertising display sign that is affixed to the side of any building or wall. 
48.  Window sign: means any sign installed on the inside of a window, whether attached to the window or not, for purposes of viewing from outside the premises. 
D.  Permits required. Any person wishing to construct, erect, alter, move or post a sign in the City of South Daytona shall first secure a permit after submitting plans and specifications to the community development department (hereinafter known as the "department"). An application form provided by the department shall require the applicant to include the following information: size, type, structure, heights, proximity to building, rights-of-way, streets and general location. 
1.  Work which may be performed by a property owner or lessee: 
a.  Painting the face of any freestanding or wall sign; 
b.  Installation or attachment of any individual letters, which does not require electrical service or structural modification of the surface or wall to which such letters are being attached. 
2.  Other work shall be performed by a sign contractor, general contractor or building contractor licensed with the city to perform such work: 
a.  Construction, installation, erection or electrical connection of any sign which is internally illuminated; 
b.  Construction, installation or erection of any new sign being installed under the provisions of this section. 
3.  Application. All applications filed by either the owner, lessee or contractor shall include: 
a.  Name, address and telephone number of owners of property; 
b.  Name, address and telephone number of licensed sign company erecting the sign; 
c.  Street address or legal description of the property upon which the sign is to be located; 
d.  The height, size, shape, style, colors, materials and location of the sign; 
e.  Written permission of the owner, his lessee or agent, to erect the sign; 
f.  A plan, sketch blueprint, or similar presentation drawn to scale, showing all pertinent structural and electrical details, wind pressure requirements and materials in accordance with the city's adopted building code. The city reserves the right to require plan certification by a licensed registered engineer, if deemed necessary by the chief building official; and 
g.  A statement verifying the height, size, shape and location of existing signage on the premises. 
4.  Issuance of permit. Upon receipt of an application for a sign permit, the department shall review the plans, specifications and other data relating to such sign and, if considered necessary, inspect the premises upon which the sign is proposed to be erected. If the proposed sign is in compliance with this section and all other applicable laws and codes of the city, a sign permit shall be issued upon receipt of the permit fee. 
5.  Permit fees. Permit fees under this section shall be set by resolutions of the city council. Sign permit fees shall be in accordance with the standard schedule of building permit fees. In addition, an annual inspection and renewal fee shall be charged for all existing signs within the city; it will be added to the annual local business tax receipt fee of each business. 
6.  Permit expiration. The requirements are the same as for a standard building permit, i.e. the permit expires after six months from date of issuance unless the work has begun; even after the work has begun, any sign permit will automatically expire 12 months after date of issuance; all permits expire after work is completed and accepted by the city. 
7.  Sign bond. The requirement for a sign bond shall be limited to temporary signage and shall only be imposed in cases where city records show that in the past the person responsible for the signage has not removed it in a timely manner. When required, the amount of this sign bond shall be $150.00, which shall be returned to the applicant upon timely removal of the signage. 
E.  Exempt actions and signs. Exemption from the requirement to obtain a sign permit shall be permitted as follows: 
1.  Ordinary maintenance -Maintenance, painting, repainting, cleaning or other normal maintenance and repair of a sign not involving painting or repainting of copy are or structural or electrical changes. Section 2301.7 of the Standard Building Code also applies. 
2.  Change of copy -Changing of the advertising copy or message on an existing approved changeable copy sign. 
3.  Window displays -Changes in the content of show window displays within the building. 
4.  Instructional signs -Instructional signs which are located entirely on the property to which they pertain, do not advertise a business, and do not exceed three square feet in area. Entrance and exit signs may contain a corporate logo or similar identifying insignia not exceeding one square foot in size. 
5.  Governmental signs -Governmental signs for control of traffic and other regulatory purposes, street signs, danger signs, railroad crossing signs, signs of public service companies indicating danger, and officially authorized aids to public service or safety. 
6.  Interior signs -Signs located within any building or building complex, or within an enclosed lobby or court. 
7.  Symbols or insignia -Religious symbols, commemorative plaques of recognized historical agencies, or identification emblems of religious orders or historical agencies, provided that no such symbol, plaque or emblem shall exceed four square feet in area. 
8.  Public information signs -Signs used to provide public information or direction erected by authority of a public body. 
9.  Window signs -Any sign installed on the inside of a window, whether attached to the window or not, for purposes of viewing from outside the premises except that no such signage may cover more than 50 percent of the area of the window. 
10.  Certain special signs -The following types of signs: "No trespassing/dumping" signs; freestanding memorial signs or tablets, and names of building and dates of erection when cut into any masonry surface or when constructed of bronze or other noncombustible materials and attached to the surface of a building; legal notices and official instruments; holiday lights and seasonal decorations; public warning signs; menu signs of less that two square fee mounted at the entrances to restaurants; temporary window signs which are removed in ten days; works off art which do not constitute advertising; "no smoking" or "shut off engine" type signs accompanying fuel dispensing pumps at gas stations. 
11.  Removal (not relocation) of a sign. 
F.  General. 
1.  Unsafe and unlawful signs. If the chief building official finds that any sign or other advertising structure regulated herein is unsafe or insecure, or is a menace to the public, or has been constructed or erected or is being maintained in violation of the provisions of this section, he shall give written notice of violation to the permittee. If the permittee fails to remove or alter the structure so as to comply with the standards herein within ten days after issuance of such notice, such sign or other advertising structure may be removed or altered to comply by the chief building official at the expense of the permittee or owner who refuses to issue a permit to any permittee or owner who refuses to pay costs so assessed. The chief building official may cause any sign or other advertising structure which is an immediate peril to persons or property to be removed summarily and without notice. 
2.  General safety. Signs must not create a traffic or fire hazard, be dangerous to the general welfare, or interfere with the free use of public streets or sidewalks. 
3.  Obstruction of ingress or egress. No sign shall be attached to or placed against a building in such a manner as to prevent or impede ingress and egress through any door or window of any building, nor shall any sign obstruct or be attached to a fire escape. 
4.  Sign maintenance. The sign maintenance standard of the city is that all signs must be kept in good repair, clean, free of rust and flaking paint with unbroken sign faces and functional bulbs; it also means that all signs should be maintained in substantially the same condition as when they were erected; it also means that they shall be kept legible and complete, as well as safe and repaired in a timely manner. 
The chief building official shall inspect annually, or at such times as he deems necessary, each sign or other advertising structure regulated by this Code for the purpose of ascertaining whether it is properly secured and whether it is in need of maintenance, repair or removal. Those signs which he finds to be in need of maintenance, repair, removal, or otherwise not in conformance with applicable regulations will be brought to the attention of the owner. The owner or his designated agent shall be required to obtain the necessary permits for either returning the sign to proper condition or removing it. 
5.  Removal of abandoned signs. Any sign now or hereafter existing which, for 180 consecutive calendar days, no longer advertises a bona fide and active business conducted, or a product sold, shall immediately, upon expiration of the 180-day period, be deemed abandoned and thereafter, within ten days after issuance of written notification from the chief building official, it shall be taken down and removed by the owner, agent or person having the beneficial use of the building or structure upon which such sign may be found. Upon failure to comply with such notice within the time specified in the order, the chief building official is hereby authorized to cause removal of such sign, and any expense incident thereto shall be paid by the owner of the building or structure to which such sign is attached. Billboards maintained in good condition shall not be subject to removal under this section due to temporary absence of advertising material thereon. 
6.  Prohibited signs. The following signs are prohibited in the city: 
a.  Those that communicate obscenity or indecency. 
b.  Billboards. 
c.  Snipe signs. 
d.  Flashing signs. 
e.  Signs on or over public lands. 
f.  Projecting signs. 
g.  Parked vehicles used principally as advertising signs. 
h.  Spectacular signs. 
i.  All signs not specifically permitted or exempted by this Code. 
j.  Signs that contain any lighting or control mechanism that causes unreasonable interference with radio, television, or other communication signals. 
k.  Searchlights used to advertise or promote a business or to attract customers to a property. 
l.  Signs with visible moving, revolving, or rotating parts or visible mechanical movement of any description or other apparent visible movement achieved by electrical, electronic, or mechanical means, except for traditional barber poles. 
m.  Signs with lights or illuminations that flash, move, rotate, scintillate, blink, flicker or vary in intensity or color including "electronic message center" signs, which term includes signs that display time-temperature-date. However, existing electronic message center signs in operation within the city prior to October 1, 2008, shall be allowed to remain at their current location as a nonconforming structure. The existing electronic message center signs shall be programmed to have a minimum display time of five seconds per message and a change time not to exceed two seconds. All existing electronic message center signs shall reduce the sign lighting intensity by 50 percent during the hours between 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. daily. 
n.  Strings of light bulbs used on commercially developed parcels for commercial purposes, other than traditional holiday decorations. 
o.  Signs that incorporate projected images, emit any sound that is intended to attract attention, or involve the use of live animals. 
p.  Signs that emit audible sound, odor, or visible matter such as smoke or steam. 
q.  Signs that obstruct the vision of pedestrians, cyclists, or motorists traveling on or entering public streets. 
r.  Signs, within ten feet of public right-of-way or 100 feet of traffic-control lights, that contain red or green lights that might be confused with traffic control lights. 
s.  Signs that are of such intensity or brilliance as to cause glare or impair the vision of any motorist, cyclist, or pedestrian using or entering a public way, or that are a hazard or a nuisance to occupants of any property because of glare or other characteristics. 
t.  Signs on the interior of store windows to the extent that they exceed 50 percent of the area of the window. 
7.  Construction standards. 
a.  Compliance with Building Code - All signs shall comply with the appropriate detailed provisions of the municipal construction and electrical codes and the construction standards hereinafter set forth. 
b.  Structural designs - All signs that contain more than 40 square feet in area or are erected over 20 feet in height shall be designed by an engineer registered in the State of Florida. Structural drawings shall be prepared and sealed by the engineer and submitted prior to a permit being issued. Wind load calculations shall be contained in the engineering drawings. 
c.  Request for wind load calculations - The chief building official may request wind load calculations for signs less than 40 square feet in area prior to issuing a permit. 
d.  Design and strength of walls - A wall must be designed for and have sufficient strength to support any sign which is attached thereto. 
e.  Sign identification and marking - Each sign hereinafter erected or remodeled shall bear, in a permanent position thereon, a clearly legible identification plate stating the name and address of the owner of the sign, the person or firm responsible for its construction and erection and the date of erection. Electrical signs shall be marked with input amperages at the full load input. 
f.  Clearance from high voltage power lines - Signs shall be located in such a way that they maintain a clearance of ten feet from all overhead electrical conductors and a three-foot clearance from all secondary voltage service drops. 
g.  Ground sign materials - All ground sign structures shall be self-supported structures erected on and attached to concrete foundations. Such structures shall be fabricated only from galvanized steel or of an equivalent corrosion resistant material. 
h.  Electric signs - All electric signs shall be certified by the sign contractor that the sign meets standards established by the current edition of the National Electric Code. All electric signs shall be erected and installed by a licensed sign contractor. The electrical connection to a power source shall be performed by a licensed electrical contractor. 
i.  Supports and braces - Metal supports and braces shall be adequate for wind loadings. Wire or cable supports shall have a safety factor of four times the required strength. All metal, wire cable supports and braces, and all bolts used to attach signs to brackets or brackets and signs to the supporting buildings or structures shall be of galvanized steel or of an equivalents corrosion resistant material. All such sign supports shall be an integral part of the sign. 
j.  Sign anchoring - No sign shall be suspended by chains or other devices that will allow the sign to swing due to wind action. Signs shall be anchored to prevent any lateral movement that would cause wear on supporting members or connections. 
k.  Prohibited sign face materials for permanent ground and pole signs - The following materials are included among the materials which shall be generally prohibited for use as a sign face for a permanent ground or pole sign due to their lack of durability, likelihood of losing original shape, or other undesirable features: plywood, particle board, masonite, paper, fabric, etc. However, if it is shown to the satisfaction of the chief building official that an otherwise prohibited material has been modified or packaged to eliminate any unacceptable characteristics, he may, on a case-by-case basis allow the material to be used. 
8.  Modifications to existing signs. Modifications of existing conforming signs may be permitted under the following conditions: 
a.  Modifications shall be subject to the applicable provisions of this Code. 
b.  Modifications which alter height or sign area shall require a sign permit. 
c.  Modifications shall be consistent and compatible with the existing sign, including illumination, materials, shape and style. 
9.  Lighting generally. 
a.  Floor or ground lights, or spot lights used for the illumination of signs or otherwise, shall be shielded from the street and adjacent property. 
b.  Neon. Use of neon signs and decorative neon on signs for increased visibility shall be permitted, except that exposed (unshielded) neon shall be prohibited in residential zones. 
Use of non-sign neon to embellish or accent the outside of a building or other exterior exposure of a structure shall be limited as follows: 
1)  Plans shall be submitted to the community development department and a permit secured; and 
2)  Such use of neon shall be limited to properties along arterial roadways; and 
3)  Such use of neon shall be limited to trim along the edges of a structure; and 
4)  The neon plan must be approved by the board of adjustment and appeals after the board receives staff input and before a permit may be issued. 
10.  Overhanging public property. No sign, except bench advertising and franchised signage authorized by the city council, shall overhang any city or public property. 
G.  Permitted signs. 
1.  Residential districts. The owners or agents of any property in any residential district are hereby prohibited from erecting, replacing or moving onto any property any sign or advertisement except as follows: 
a.  One professional sign per lot, only if required by state statute, not exceeding two square feet in area. Subject sign shall list only the name of the individual business person and the occupation. An occupational sign may only be erected at the residence where the occupation is conducted. 
b.  Real estate sales or rental signs as described and limited in real estate signs of this Code. 
c.  A subdivision identification (entrance) sign may be erected at one or more entrances to new subdivisions only if detailed plans and drawings showing the planned location, size and type of sign are submitted to the city with the subdivision plan and development plans for their review and approval. Owners or agents for established subdivisions wishing to change existing entrance signs or erect new signs shall submit detailed plans to the city staff. A homeowners' association or similar entity shall exist or be created to maintain said signs. 
d.  Multifamily structures may erect one project identification sign not to exceed 32 square feet in area. Such sign shall be an unlighted or lighted ground sign, suitably landscaped to blend with the area. An ornamental entrance way may be provided if plans are submitted and approved with the original site plan and engineering drawings. Ornamental lettering depicting the project name and street address only may be placed on the side wall of a multifamily structure provided such wall faces a public street. Multifamily projects with more than one building fronting on a public street, with each building having separate access to the street, may use individual wall and entrance identification as outlined above. 
One or more directional/directory signs, not to exceed four square feet each, may be approved to identify public areas within any project. 
e.  Garage sale signs. One sign of not more than four square feet may be displayed on the property of the residence where a garage sale is being conducted pursuant to city ordinance; one additional such sign may be displayed off-premises. The off-premises sign shall be placed only where indicated on the permit. Such sign shall be displayed only during the times permitted by city ordinance and only on the date or dates for which the permit is valid. Such sign may be displayed on a public right-of-way where not otherwise prohibited by law. 
f.  Houses of worship in residential zoning districts, electing to erect freestanding signage, may be permitted a ground sign only, as follows: 
1.  The sign shall be limited to 32 square feet per sign face, 64 square feet aggregate. 
2.  There shall be a limit of one sign to each lot or parcel of property, except where such lot or parcel extends from one street to another. On corner property at intersection streets, there may be one sign placed facing each street. 
3.  The signs may be electric or non-electric; however, they shall not be illuminated between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
4.  The height of the ground sign shall be limited to a maximum of eight feet, and the vertical distance of any open space between the ground and the underside of the sign face frame shall be limited to a maximum of two feet.

Notes: 
(1)  See "houses of worship in residential districts. 
(2)  Subject sign shall list only the name of the individual practitioner and profession and only be erected at the residence where the profession is conducted, and only if the sign is required by Florida Statute. 
(3)  See "temporary signs: real estate signs." 
(4)  Such signs may be erected at one or more entrances to new subdivisions only if detailed plans and drawings showing the planned location, size and type of sign are submitted to the city with the subdivision plat and development plans for their review and approval. Such sign shall be an unlighted or lighted ground or wall sign, suitably landscaped to blend with the area. 
2.  Non-residential district signs. 
a.  Wall and roof signs: 
(1)  A roof sign may be permitted only if the chief building official has determined that a wall sign is impractical because it would physically impede the use of the related building. Such a roof sign is in lieu of the otherwise allowable wall signage and is limited in size to 36 square feet. A roof sign may not extend beyond the level of the peak of the roof. 
(2)  Single tenant buildings - Single tenant buildings shall be limited to one lighted or unlighted wall sign or roof sign on a wall or roof, the contents of which shall be limited to letters, characters and figures, or combinations thereof, naming or describing the business conducted in said premises. The area of a wall sign shall not exceed 48 square feet. If a commercial or industrial structure has more than one wall readily visible from a public right-of-way or street, or if it is located on a corner lot, one additional wall sign may be added for each visible wall with a maximum limit of three wall signs per structure; provided that the total area of all such signs shall not exceed sixty (60) square feet. Decorative facia not containing letters, characters and figures are not counted as wall signs. All such signs shall conform to the general architectural design of the buildings to which they are attached. See "construction standards" for additional requirements. In all cases, a wall or roof sign may not extend above the roofline of the structure to which it is attached. 
(3)  Multi-tenant buildings and multi-building complexes: Each tenant in such buildings shall be permitted one wall sign. The area of this sign shall be one square foot of sign area for each linear foot of store frontage, up to a maximum sign area of 48 square feet. Where a business is in a building that has more than one wall readily visible from a street, one additional wall sign may be permitted. The additional wall sign may not exceed the area of the primary sign, and the total area of both signs shall not exceed 60 square feet. Roof signs shall not be permitted for multi-tenant buildings or multi-building complexes. 
(4)  Murals shall be regulated as wall signage in the following manner: 
(a)  Murals that do not violate the size limitations for regular wall signage will be administratively processed just like any other wall signage. 
(b)  Neon or other tubular gas lighting of any kind shall not be allowed as part of any type of mural. 
(c)  Any mural must have a readily apparent relationship to the nature of the business at that location. 
(d)  The applicant for a mural shall be encouraged to limit its size to that of regularly allowed wall signage. 
(e)  Murals proposed to be larger than regularly allowed wall signage must be considered by the land development regulation board (LDRB) using the following guidelines: 
(1)  Staff must present its analysis and recommendation to the LDRB before the board makes its decision; 
(2)  The applicant must demonstrate that there is good reason for having a mural larger that a normal wall sign; 
(3)  The size of the mural shall not exceed 50 percent of the area of the wall where it is to be placed; 
(4)  The color scheme of the mural must be approved by the LDRB; 
(5)  A mural shall not contain more than a "small amount of wording"; 
(6)  Murals larger that a normal wall sign shall be limited in location to arterial roadways (i.e. Beville Rd., U.S.1, and Nova Rd.); 
(7)  If a mural is larger than a normal wall sign, no other business sign shall be allowed on the mural wall; 
(8)  A Mural shall not pose a potential traffic hazard distraction; 
(9)  If the applicant's proposal is denied by the LDRB and a variance or appeal from the decision of that board is sought, the variance or appeal request shall be submitted to the board of adjustments and appeals. 
(5)  Window signs: 
(a)  Window sign defined: A window sign is considered a wall sign and means any sign placed upon an exterior window of a building and includes any sign placed upon the outside or the inside of the window for purposes of viewing from the outside of the window. 
(b)  Window signage shall not cover more than one-third of the window surface. 
(c)  Signage located on the inside of a building and directly viewable from outside the window is considered window signage if it is located within three feet of the inside of the window, even though it may not be attached to the window. 
(d)  Since window signage is considered wall signage, the area of such a sign counts against the total area of wall signage allowed. 
(e)  There shall be no limit on the number of window signs allowed on any one window; however, the area of all such window signs counts against the total area of wall signage allowed. 
(f)  Window signage on the inside of a particular window is not to be considered separately from window signage on the outside of that window-e.g. if signage on the inside of a window covers a certain one-third of the window and another is placed on the outside of the window covering a different one-third of the window, taken together they must be considered in violation of the requirement that no more than one-third of the window space shall be covered with window signage. 
b.  Freestanding signs (ground or pole signs). 
(1)  One ground or pole sign may be permitted subject to the following conditions: 
(a)  A single-tenant or multi-tenant building may be permitted one freestanding sign. Shopping center out-parcels shall be treated in the same manner. 
(b)  Shopping centers or commercial and industrial parcels with more than one building may be permitted one freestanding sign for each 150 linear feet of street frontage up to a maximum of three such signs per property in single ownership. 
(2)  The maximum size of any freestanding sign shall be as specified in Table 16, with the exception that the maximum size of any freestanding sign in a Business Neighborhood Commercial (BNC) District shall be limited to 20 square feet. 
(3)  Multiple frontage lots are permitted one additional freestanding sign. The size of this sign is based upon the classification of the second street as follows: 
Street 
Classification Percent of 
Primary Sign Arterial 100% Collector 75% Local street 50%  
(4)  Pole signs must have at least eight feet clearance between the bottom of the sign and the ground. The maximum height of pole signs shall be 15 feet, except that for shopping centers, the maximum height shall be 20 feet. 
(5)  Freestanding signs shall be located so as to avoid any visual interference with ingress and egress for the site. 
(6)  Only one freestanding sign per tract shall be allowed within 75 feet of intersections. 
(7)  The minimum setback from the street right-of-way shall be five feet, unless the chief building official determines that a lesser setback is necessary to avoid impeding the physical use of the property. 
(8)  Notwithstanding other size limitations in this Code, freestanding theater advertising signs in shopping centers shall be subject to the following size limitations: the total sign area shall not exceed 250 square feet, with the theater identification portion not exceeding 150 square feet and the marquee portion not exceeding 200 square feet. 
(9)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code, freestanding signs within the boundaries of the Ridgewood Redevelopment District (CRA) shall be "ground signs" (i.e. "monument signs") as defined in this code unless a hardship variance is obtained from the board of adjustments and appeals. All "non-ground" freestanding signs installed prior to the effective date of this provision shall be allowed to continue to exist until one of the following events occurs-after which such signs must be promptly removed: (1) a period of ten years goes by after the date that this article takes effect (this is also known as an "amortization period"); (2) the sign is damaged to the extent of 50 percent or more of its assessed value as determined by the Volusia County Property Appraiser; (3) the sign deteriorates to the extent that its assessed value, as determined by the Volusia County Property Appraiser, has been reduced to 25 percent or less of its replacement cost; or (4) the sign is being replaced with another freestanding sign. Ordinary repair and maintenance shall be allowed on existing "non-ground" signs. 
3.  Signs in shopping centers. 
a.  All proposed shopping centers shall submit a comprehensive signage program as a part of the development plan review process. 
b.  A shopping center with an interior mall or courtyard may have one wall identification sign not to exceed 60 square feet at each principal entrance. 
c.  Each business with a public entrance directly to the parking area shall be permitted one wall, canopy, under canopy, or awning sign for each entrance. The size of the sign shall not exceed one square foot for each foot of store frontage. The maximum size of all such signs shall be 60 square feet, except for major stores in excess of 50,000 square feet of rental space. These major stores may be permitted a wall sign not to exceed 120 square feet in area. 
d.  Interior signage shall not be subject to these regulations, except that such signs shall not be animated or flashing and must be in compliance with the appropriate codes and standards. 
e.  In shopping centers with canopies, one under-canopy sign may be permitted for each business. This under-canopy sign shall not exceed four square feet. It shall be oriented so as to provide information to pedestrians under the canopy and should provide a minimum of eight feet clearance between the bottom of the sign and the sidewalk. 
4.  Gasoline service stations. Gasoline service stations shall be permitted the same numbers and types of signs as authorized for other commercial areas. Signs advertising prices, services, etc., shall not be permitted unless contained within the authorized area of the permitted wall, ground or pole signs. 
Gasoline service stations shall be allowed to have one sign on each separate canopy face, not to exceed one square foot per lineal foot of canopy face length.

H.  Temporary signs. 
1.  Political signs. This section shall govern the erection and display of political signs within the city and shall not be construed to apply to signs of any other nature which are regulated by other laws of the city. 
a.  Permits are required for any candidate desiring to erect or display a political sign or signs within the city. Such a permit shall be issued to the applicant by the city upon payment of a permit fee in the amount of $10.00 and the posting of a $100.00 cash bond for municipal election candidates and a $25.00 bond for non-municipal election candidates. The obligation of said bond shall be the applicant's compliance with the provisions of this division and all other applicable law. 
b.  No such signs shall be erected or displayed earlier than 30 days prior to the primary, special or general election to which the same is directed. Each such sign shall be removed within seven days after such election, except that the signs for a winning candidate in a primary election may be maintained until seven (7) days after the general election. 
c.  No such signs shall be erected or displayed on public sidewalks, on public rights-of-way, or on any other public property. Additionally, no sign shall be attached to or on any telephone, telegraph, utility pole, public signage structure, tree or shrubbery. 
d.  No such signs shall be erected or displayed on private property without the consent of the owner of the property. 
e.  No such sign shall be displayed in such a manner as to obstruct the vision of motorists at street intersections or to otherwise create a safety hazard. 
f.  No such sign shall exceed four square feet (per side) in area in any residential zone or 32 square feet in area in any commercial or industrial zone. 
g.  Residents of the city shall be permitted to display on the property on which they reside a maximum of five political signs without obtaining a sign permit or posting the bond required herein. The erection or display of such signs shall be subject to the regulations and restrictions set forth herein. 
h.  Signs displayed in violation of the provisions of this section may be removed by a representative of the city, without notice. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine in the amount of $5.00 for each sign in violation. In the event that signs are erected or displayed by holders of political sign permits in violation of the provisions of this Section, the bond posted by the permit holder pursuant to the code may be used for the removal of such signs at the rate of $5.00 per sign. 
2.  Special event advertising. In commercial and industrial zones, and after city council approval in specified residential areas, the use of temporary signs banner signs and pennants to promote an extraordinary business event, such as a grand opening, going-out-of-business sale or race week promotion shall be permitted for a limited time. No business or non-profit entity may utilize any of the temporary signs permitted herein for more than 30 days in any calendar year. The permit for the use of a temporary sign shall specify the day the sign(s) shall be erected and the day the sign(s) shall be removed. All temporary signs shall be reinforced at their attaching points, and the cables, wires or ropes used to support such signs must be of a size and material to be safe and capable of withstanding adverse weather conditions. All temporary signs shall be contained within the property boundaries or lease area of the business the sign advertises, and no sign or cable shall be attached to any telegraph, telephone or utility pole. No sign permitted herein shall be permitted to be located in the same location for more than 30 continuous days, no matter what business is utilizing the sign. If a sign permitted herein is to be used by more than one business when those businesses are located on the same property of lease area, the sign must be completely removed from the property or lease area on which the businesses are located for a period of at least seven days prior to its utilization by the second business. If the sign permitted herein has not been removed for at least seven days prior to its utilization by the second business, no permit shall be issued; and the sign shall be treated as if no permit has been issued, and the penalty provisions of this Article shall apply. No sign permitted herein shall be erected until approved by the community development department and payment of the permit fees. Temporary signs shall be erected no earlier than two days prior to the special event and shall be removed no later than two days after its termination. In no case shall any business be allowed to utilize any type of sign or combination of signs permitted under this section for more than 30 days within a calendar year. Failure of any business to comply with the terms of this section shall subject the permittee to the penalty and enforcement provisions of the Code of Ordinances, as such provisions may be applicable. 
3.  Real estate signs. In any residential zoning district of the city or any subdivision thereof, the property owner or any real estate agent, broker or salesperson is hereby prohibited from erecting, displaying, replacing or moving onto any property any sign or advertisement for the sale or rental of the property except under the following regulations of this section: 
a.  There shall be a limit of one real estate sign (in addition to any allowable "open house" sign) for an on each lot or parcel, except where such lot or parcel extends from one street to another (including intersection streets), one sign may be placed facing each street. Each such sign shall not exceed five square feet in area including all riders and the frame. 
b.  All signs herein provided shall be erected in a neat, workmanlike manner and shall contain only neat and legible printing or painting. 
c.  No signs shall be placed on trees, shrubbery, vines or upon any part of a building except where such building is constructed contiguous to the street or sidewalk, in which case the said sign may be affixed to the building. 
d.  Where any property owner, real estate agent, broker or salesman is holding a house or building open for inspection to the general public, that person may display one open house sign on the premises and up to two other open house signs off the premises on private property, by agreement with the property owner. These signs may not exceed four square feet and may be displayed during a maximum of three days of the week. 
e.  One real estate sign up to 12 square feet in area may be permitted in residential zones on un-subdivided property of five acres or more. 
f.  For platted subdivisions which are situated such that on-premises real estate signs cannot be seen by the general public from the nearest main arterial collector roadway to which the subdivision connects, one off-premises real estate advertising sign of not to exceed 32 square feet may be erected within public view of said roadway so long as fewer than 80 percent of the lots in the subdivision have been sold. The permit for this sign shall expire 12 months from date of issuance or at the point that at least 80 percent of the lots in the subdivision have been sold, whichever comes first, but said permit is eligible for one or more renewals subject to the same conditions for permit expiration so long as fewer than 80 percent of the lots in the subdivision have been sold. This sign may be erected on private property by agreement with the property owner. 
g.  For subdivisions actively selling platted homesites which do not have direct access from an arterial or collector road, up to two off-premise advertising/ directional signs may be erected in separate locations. Each of these signs may not exceed four square feet in area. These signs may be erected on private property by agreement with the property owner. 
h.  One on-premises real estate sign up to 12 square feet in area may be permitted to advertise homesites of platted subdivisions. The permit shall expire after 12 months from date of issuance, but may be renewed upon expiration for successive additional 12-month periods until 80 percent of the homesites in the subdivision have been sold. Once that threshold has been reached, the sign must be removed within 30 days. 
i.  Where a builder-owner has a model home(s) for sale in a platted subdivision that is so situated that on-premises signs cannot be seen by the general public from the nearest arterial or collector roadway, the builder-owner may display up to two model home/directional signs on private property with agreement of the property owner and close to the nearest arterial or collector. The sign shall not exceed 24 inches wide by 18 inches high and must be mounted on a sturdy metal support frame. These signs may also be located on city right-of-way only with the approval of the city council and based upon a finding that the location of the signs on private property is not a viable alternative. 
j.  One real estate sign up to 24 square feet in area may be permitted on property in commercial and industrial zones provided the property has frontage on a public right-of-way or street. If the property extends from one street to another, one sign may be placed on each street; this includes intersection streets. 
k.  Sign riders shall be allowed only for "for sale" type real estate signs. Up to two riders shall be allowed per sign provided that no more than one rider is affixed to any one side of the main sign and provided that the square footage of the total sign, including riders and frame, does not exceed five square feet. No such rider shall have a length exceeding that of the underlying base sign along the edge to which it is affixed. 
l.  Freestanding real estate signs on property in commercial and industrial zones may not exceed eight feet in height. For such signs, the minimum setbacks from the street right-of-way and side property lines shall be five feet. 
m.  A sign permit shall be required for any real estate sign exceeding six square feet in size. 
n.  Real estate signs which no longer legitimately advertise the up-to-date "for rent", "for sale", "for lease", etc. status of a property are to be removed within ten days of ceasing to correctly advertise the status of the property. For example, once a property is sold, the "for sale" sign must be removed within ten days of the closing. 
o.  Real estate signs which state "sold" must be removed within ten days of closing. 
p.  If a real estate sign displays zoning information, that information must be accurate, otherwise the sign must be removed from the property. 
q.  On commercial and industrial property, "for rent" or "for lease" real estate signs not mounted on a permanent sign structure are limited in duration of display to 90 days per calendar year; extensions may be given for good cause. This limitation does not apply to such signs mounted on a permanent sign structure. 
r.  On commercial and industrial property, the time limit of the permit for a "for sale" sign which is not mounted on a permanent sign structure shall be 365 days or the date of closing upon sale, whichever occurs first; however, the sign permit for such a sign may be renewed for one or more subsequent periods of up to 180 days each for good cause as determined by the permitting authority. "For sale" signs mounted on a permanent sign structure are not subject to this limitation. 
4.  Portable electric. Portable electric signs are hereby classified as temporary signs and may be permitted in any commercial or industrial district subject to the provisions of this Code, including the following conditions: 
a.  Flashing devices of any kind are prohibited. 
b.  Bulb size is limited to 15 watts; and the colors red, green, blue and amber are prohibited. 
c.  No sign may use the words "stop", "look", "danger", or any other word, phrase, symbol or character in such a manner as to interfere with, mislead or confuse traffic. 
d.  Signs shall not obstruct pedestrian or vehicular traffic, nor utilize existing parking spaces in established parking areas. 
e.  Signs shall be securely anchored to the ground and, if lighted, shall comply with the applicable provisions of the current National Electrical Code. 
5.  Other temporary signs. 
a.  Temporary signage may be allowed in lieu of permanent signage for a maximum of 30 consecutive days where the administrative official determines that the circumstances so warrant and only if such temporary signage is precedent to the erection of permanent signage. Such signage shall not be any larger than what is allowed for a permanent sign. Such signage shall be limited to no more than one wall sign and/or one freestanding sign if the sign regulations for permanent signage, as applied to the particular case, allow at least one wall sign and/or one freestanding sign. 
I.  Miscellaneous sign regulations. 
1.  Awnings. 
a.  Illuminated awnings. Use of awnings shall be regulated under the following: 
(1)  The use of copy on an awning, and illuminated awnings shall be regulated by the applicable provisions of this code for wall signs, including the requirement to obtain a sign permit. 
(2)  Maximum height, measured on a vertical plane from the point of attachment at the top of the awning to a point of attachment at the top of the awning to a point horizontal to the lowest edge of fabric, shall not exceed five feet. 
(3)  Illuminated awnings shall be prohibited for the following uses: 
(a)  Residential uses. 
(b)  Non-residential uses in residential zones. 
b.  Non-illuminated awnings. Non-illuminated awnings shall be treated as signage only if they contain words, letters, numbers or some other type of graphic information. Signage on awnings shall be treated as wall signage. 
2.  A master sign plan is required for a shopping or multi-building complex as noted herein and should be included in the development plans submitted for review. 
3.  Traffic control signs such as "enter," "exit," "one-way," "stop," etc., are allowed to the extent necessary to properly control on-site traffic flow. MUTCD standards shall apply. Other signs may contain logo, and shall not exceed two square feet. All traffic control signs must be approved as part of the master sign plan. 
4.  Directory signage is allowed in multi-building commercial, industrial, or multi-family complexes to identify locations by building. These may be wall or freestanding signs. Freestanding signs must be a ground sign. Directory signs shall not exceed 15 square feet. 
5.  Flags. 
a.  No more than three flags or insignia of governmental, charitable, religious, fraternal or other organizations may be displayed on any one parcel of land. The maximum width from top to bottom of any flag shall be 20 percent of the total height of the flag pole, or in the absences of a flag pole, 20 percent of the distance from the top of the flag or insignia to the ground. 
b.  Flags or insignias which read "model," "open," "open house" or any other phrase which identifies property for sale or lease purposes may be displayed as noted in the real estate section of this chapter. The maximum height of such flags shall be eight feet and maximum size shall be 15 square feet. 
(1)  Main entrance to a residential subdivision or planned residential development - two flags 
(2)  Entrance to a multi-family project or sub-phase of a planned residential development - two flags. 
(3)  Single-family or duplex model home lot - two flags. 
(4)  Townhouse or villa model - two flags 
6.  Bus benches and shelters. Nothing contained in this Code shall be construed to prohibit the placement or construction of bus benches or bus shelters in connection with public transportation and from the painting or attachment of signs thereto; provided, however, that such bus benches and bus shelters upon which signs are painted or attached shall be placed or constructed under and pursuant to the terms of a license agreement or other contract executed on behalf of the city wherein the conditions concerning the placement, design, construction, number and signage connected with such bus benches and bus shelters, as applicable, shall be set forth. 
7.  Parking of vehicles used for advertising purposes. No person shall park any car, truck, trailer, boat or other vehicle on a public right-of-way, public property, or private property so as to be clearly visible from a public right- of-way, which has attached thereto or located thereon any sign or advertising device for the primary purpose of providing advertisement of products or directing people to a business or business activity. This provision is not intended to prohibit any form of public vehicular signage such as a sign attached to a public bus. Neither shall this provision be a sign lettered on or attached to a motor vehicle in a manner to primarily identify the vehicle with the business it serves so long as the sign is less than six square feet in area, and the vehicle is regularly used for transportation in the conduct of the business. 
8.  Non-conforming signs. Any sign which is rendered non-conforming by the enactment of these sign regulations shall be allowed to continue in a non-conforming status under the following conditions. 
a.  Non-conforming signs shall be maintained and repaired until their elimination date, but they shall not be structurally or mechanically extended or altered to further the non-conformity. Replacement or repainting of the sign face shall be permitted. 
b.  Tolerance provision: Existing non-conforming signs with reference to their existing dimensions, shall be allowed to exceed the height and size standards of this Code by a degree not exceeding 25 percent for the life of the sign. 
c.  Non-conforming signs shall be classified as either Type A, "In Excess of Three Freestanding (pole or ground) Signs Per Property Under Single Ownership," or Type B, "Other," It should be noted that Type B signs include up to three non-conforming freestanding signs per property, and all wall and roof signs. 
d.  Type A signs (the "in excess of three freestanding signs per property" category) shall be allowed to retain their non-conforming status until December 31, 1997 the elimination date, at which time all such non-conforming signs shall be eliminated. For example, if a shopping center presently has seven non-conforming freestanding signs, the owner must eliminate four of them within the approximately five-year period; however, the remaining three signs would be classified as Type B signs, with a remaining life of approximately ten years. 
e.  Type B signs shall be allowed to retain their non- conforming status until December 31, 2002 the elimination date, at which time all such non-conforming signs shall be eliminated, except for those for which the sole non-conformity is that they do not meet the five-foot setback requirement (see provision 8-f below). 
f.  The five-foot setback requirement shall be tied to any substantial change in the building to which the subject sign is related. Any Type B sign whose sole non-conformity is a violation of the five-foot setback requirement shall be allowed to retain its non-conforming status until such time as a substantial change in the building occurs. The term "substantial change" shall include, but not be limited to, such phenomena as replacing the existing building with a new one, substantial exterior remodeling or modernization of the existing building, or putting an addition on the existing building. The term "substantial change" shall not include such activities as repair and maintenance, including painting. A five-foot setback only non- conforming sign could last beyond the usual elimination date for a Type B sign if there is no substantial change in the related building by that date. However, Type A signs are not eligible for five-foot setback only consideration. 
g.  Any nonconforming sign shall be brought into conformance if the sign is damaged to the extent of 50 percent or more of its assessed value as determined by the Volusia County Property Appraiser. 
h.  Any nonconforming sign shall be brought into conformance if the sign deteriorates to the extent that its assessed value as determined by the Volusia County Property Appraiser becomes 25 percent or less of its replacement cost. 
Table 8-3. Non-Conforming Sign Elimination Deadlines 
Type A Type B 5-foot Setback (>3 freestanding signs/property) (all other freestanding signs plus all other signs) (Type B sign with only a setback non-conformity) Elimination Deadline: * 12-31-97 (approximately five years) * 12-31-02 (approximately ten years) * Substantial change in related bldg. if after Dec. 31, 2002)  
* Note: These deadlines would be superseded by the following conditions- furtherance of the nonconformity; damage to 50 percent or more of assessed value; or deterioration to extent that assessed value less than 25 percent of replacement cost. 
9.  Ad hoc sign code advisory committee: The city council may, at its discretion, appoint a five-member ad hoc sign code advisory committee for the purpose of obtaining, as needed, community-based advice concerning such matters as reviewing proposed changes to the sign code, and finding solutions to problems encountered in implementing the sign code. Some, but not all, of the members of this committee shall be business persons doing business in the City of South Daytona. This committee may provide advice and recommendations to the city, but it shall have no power to require action on the part of city or any other party. The committee shall meet solely upon the request of the city council, or the city manager, or the designee of the city manager. 
10.  Off premises right-of-way franchise signs: The city council may authorize the execution of a franchise agreement, either exclusive or nonexclusive, with a qualified franchise which allows said franchisee to install, operate, and maintain standardized, off-premises advertising signage at selected locations in public right-of-way for a limited period of time. Such an agreement may contain provisions that conflict with certain other provisions of the sign code by allowing, for example, placement of advertising signage in the public right-of-way, installation of free-standing signs to a height greater than 15 feet, and provision of off-premises advertising. Where the provisions of the franchise agreement conflict with those found elsewhere in the sign code, the provisions of the franchise agreement shall prevail.
